content:
Posted: December 29, 2016
												Excerpts from a war diary:Day 1: My name is Bruno. I was a chef once. Had a cooking show. It was a good life. Doesn't matter now, here in the middle of a war. Now it's just me and a couple people I've met, trying to survive together in this hellscape. Katia, a former reporter, and Pavle, a football star, or so he says. They seem like good people, at least.Day 2: We've established ourselves in an abandoned house. Found some useful things, made ourselves as comfortable as possible. We have decided to take sleeping, guarding, and scavenging in turns. Maybe we can make it through this.Day 4: Had a visitor today; someone desperate for help. Apparently a shell hit a tenement nearby, buried some people in the rubble. Pavle ran off to help. He's a good man; we'll do without him for a day.Day 7: Pavle went on a scavenging run to the super market last night, but didn't return. We're worried. Katia has volunteered to go look for him tonight. I hope nothing has happened to him...Day 8: Pavle is dead. Katia found his body last night at the super market. He apparently went down fighting, crowbar in hand; but he'd been shot. A woman Katia found there told of a girl who'd been saved from an assault by a soldier the night before. It seems Pavle jumped in to save the girl. She got away; he died a hero. We weren't together long, but we'll miss him.Day 10: It's difficult with one fewer person to help, but it's also one less mouth to feed, at least. And Katia managed to salvage a good bit from the store. But it's already running low.Day 11: A girl came to the house today looking for somewhere to stay. Her name is Zlata. She's cute, and she's got a lot of positive energy. We let her join us. Should help bring things back up after losing Pavle. Katia and I have been pretty depressed since he died.Day 13: Zlata has been great. She somehow knows just what to say to make us feel better. Though we are all a bit hungry from lack of food. Hopefully we can find some more soon.Day 15: As if the hunger wasn't bad enough, the looters make it intollerable. They've been hitting us relentlessly the last few nights. We've lost a lot, and have gotten a few scratches for our trouble. Katia says it's time to go for a sure thing. She plans on going out to rob a quiet neighborhood to the north tonight. It's not ideal, but we're getting more and more desperate. I just hope we can live with ourselves when this is all over...Day 16: Katia got some good food and meds from a house last night. She said she stole them from an older couple. She's pretty torn up about it. Said the old man pleaded for her to leave them alone. She took as much as she could bear to take from them. Tried to leave them some food and medicine. This war is no good for anyone!Day 18: Katia came back from a scavenging run with some serious knife wounds! We knew the area she went was dangerous - she took our knife with her - but apparently this city is full of psychos now! She said she got the jump on this guy, but he still messed her up before he went down. But she managed to save someone from them. We've patched her up as well as we can and she's sleeping it off. I'm not sure she's going to make it without better care though...Day 20: Zlata is gone. She went out last night to look for more medical supplies for Katia, but she hasn't come back. She's gone, like Pavle before her. Katia is still in bad shape, and looters hit me last night too, so now I'm not much better off. What a miserable month it's been. No sign of improvement either. I'm beginning to wonder why we are still trying...Day 21: Katia finally gave in last night. She was a fighter, surviving as long as she did with those wounds. I'm alone now. No food, only a few meds left by some idiot who thought I'd hold them for someone else. Doesn't matter. No one is making it out of this mess. Going to head to the construction site in town tonight. I hear there may be good supplies there; but more likely a faster death than bleeding out from my wounds. It's been three weeks since this hell began. I'm ready for it to be over anyway... So I guess this is goodbye.== Good game, solid mechanics, enveloping personal stories, dark, touching, desperate. A good (bad) experience that I highly recommend, but don't expect "fun" in the classical sense. It's basically an interactive tragedy. Unless, perhaps, you make it through. Which I have not so far.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												I don't normally like survival or indie games but something about this game hooked me as soon as I saw the trailers. If nothing, I wanted to give it a chance because I respected the message it tried to give across. I'm glad to say I didn't regret. Everybody already mentioned the unique aspect of the game, that you play as a group of civilians trying to survive instead of soldiers so I am not going to focus too much on that. I am really glad that the makers took a risk by showing an actual civil war in place (which resonates very well in these days, unfortunately) instead of the overused zombie apocalypses we have seen over and over. The graphics are fairly simple but well done. The grey-washed color scheme and blending of hand-drawn backgrounds with digitally created characters and objects really works well together. What little there is, is done really well.Gameplay is usually good. Fairly simple point and click. During the day, you are in your hideout. You have a toolbench where you gather raw materials to build beds, different types of workbenches, beds, stoves, heaters, distillers and so on. Nearly every single one of these items have a vital role to play and you want to make sure you can have a headstart so that you will be producing trade goods (alcohol, cigarettes etc...) as much as you can to keep up with your needs. The season, weather, supplies and characters you start with are randomised and that means you can have a better or worse start and while this has some impact, it is sensible and is a good challenge for you to manage yourself. Every character has some use and are better geared towards either taking care of your home (the mechanic, the cook) while others are better towards scavenging (the fighter, the runner, the expert scavenger, the heavy lifter, the thief). There are a few characters whose skills seem very specific to the point of uselessness (Cveta for instance). Maybe I was not able to find their specific uses. But having a group consisting primarily of one type of characters or the other will definitely impede your ability to survive.At night, you go out scavenging and this is where things get more complicated. While the first few houses you find tend to be empty, as you keep going, you will find houses inhabited by soldiers, rebels, bandits, deserters and hapless survivors like you. How you deal with them will have a huge impact. I found the stealth and combat mechanics somewhat finicky but was able to get used to them fairly quickly. Anything you can interact with has a symbol on top of them which you can point and click in the usual fashion. The one issue I have is that there are no tooltips to explain what the action exactly is. In my initial playthroughs, I found the difference between the icons for "loot-unowned-item" and "steal-owned-item" the hard way. Similarly, during combat, the icons for "take cover" and "take cover and shoot" are so small that you will find yourself doubting which is which. While most of the gameplay issues and difficulties could be explained with characters not being soldiers to perform a combat task well, things like these have little excuse. Another issue I had was that some traders seemed to be on a bit of a hair trigger. In one of my first playthroughs, I managed to get access to the town square (where a lot of traders are present). Apparently, running towards them even if I was holding no weapons is a no-no because suddenly, everyone turned on me to attack. It seems like you need to approach them carefully. Sorta makes sense in a warzone I suppose, but it just doesn't make sense to have one rebel going "Hey, wanna trade?" while his friend goes "DIE!!!" Similarly, interactability with non-combat characters feels a bit too limited. A good example is the house with the old couple. The game seems to want you to have a morality struggle - Do you rob the old couple even as they are begging you not to or do you leave them alone? But nowhere is the option of saying "My friend is sick, I really need some medicine" or "Give me any medicine you got or I will shoot you". As it stands, you can't convey why you are trying to get into their house. How they responded and how you react to that would have a far more meaningful morality consequence, not to mention would still be sensible within the game's world.Gunfight as a whole is ill-advised and even when I had access to AKs and shotguns, I stuck with hiding around and stabbing people with a knife if combat was required. Almost any enemy is likely to outclass your guys with weapons and bullets are finite. Especially in the crime phase later into the game, your house will be raided nearly every night and you're better off keeping your guns and bullets for that and use any excess guns for trading. In general, sneaking is fairly well done. Definitely better than combat.The atmosphere is spot-on. The colors, the music cues, the little mood bubbles of the characters and the occasional challenges and "quests" (for the lack of a better word) really help set the mood. And these little things help you get attached to your characters. When you help your neighbours or save a girl from a drunken soldier, you will likely not do that out of an expectation of a reward (and often there is none) other than feeling good that you've done a good deed. It makes the characters feel content but I've noticed how often it make *me* feel good too. Similarly, robbing people or ignoring them even as they beg for help made the characters and myself feel absolutely sh*t. The decision of where you go in the night, what you need, if you think short term or long term and how you react to an unexpected situation makes the core of the game and can sometimes turn a good situation really bad really quickly. It is weird how attached you grow to your characters and have emotional responses even when it is independent from the game.In terms of story, there isn't much in focus. You are just trying to survive, after all. But each character has their own background of which more and more is revealed as the game goes along. If you win, the epilogue will show what came of their stories. It is a nice touch but can get a bit weird with characters that join your house later. I had a guy join the group a day before ceasefire was declared and the epilogue went on about how he met the woman he had lost contact when the war broke and so on but because he had just joined the group, I didn't know any of that so it felt as if it came a bit out of nowhere. Outside the personal stories, listening to the radio, listening to people speaking during scavenger runs and notes you find give you a better idea of the scale of war, the causes behind and how others have suffered, all help enrich the game's world.I've read a lot of reviews mentioning bugs and crashes. I had no such issues during my playthrough. It seems like the game is optimised for Alienware computers, so it might be why it ran without any problems for me. On a side note, the Alienware optimisation means the game actually synchs up with your computer's LED lighting (if you have any) and changes the color of the LEDs according to what is going on in the game, which is pretty cool.Overall, definitely recommend it.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2015
												The first five minutes of this game I was wondering if this would be my cup of tea.  All three of us were digging through piles of dirt to get to cupboards hoping to find some wood.  Seemed ok so far at best.10 minutes later, by day three, I knew what everyone was talking about.  I was worried, where will we find food?  My little band of three was hungry, tired and sore from sleeping on the floor.  In two quick game days this amazing game made me care about my little band of three to the point that I knew, tonight I'd do anything to find us some food.Or so I thought.  Night time scavenging Pavlo and I chanced upon an elderly couple in a little cottage.  The old woman sick, barely hanging on, but enough food there to last us a while.  Pavlo started grabbing whatever he could, I knew with this haul we'd make it a few more days.  Until the old man spotted us and started following us around... begging, pleading, asking us why?  I can only be grateful this game has no voiceover for the people you encounter at night-time...  His pleas was so heart wrenching, I ended up trying my best not to read what he was saying, but what I had read was enough, everytime another speech bubble came up I dreaded what he was saying and couldnt help but to look.  It all made me feel like the worthless, soulless thief I was, stealing from an old man and his sick wife.Me and Pavlo got out of there...  neither of us could take it anymore.  Pavlo is depressed, I feel terrible...Two days later Pavlo had to kill a couple a couple that attacked him after he stole their rat meat.  He is broken, won't move.  I had to end the game right there, I was feeling just like Pavlo.I took a few minutes to think how we could do better before starting another game.  How we could survive without doing these atrocious, horrible things to others...  Games have gotten under my skin before, but never quite like this.This game gets a 10/10 from me.  It will pull you in, make you FEEL the emotions your little party are experiencing... And after you have shut it down, it will stay with you, make you wonder about every bad thing you had to do.  Was there no other way?  What did we do?  Those people would surely starve, die for lack of medicine?Games don't get to you?  Try this one on for size.    We are on day 21 now... the crime spree has died down, we've managed to survive this long without doing too much harm to others... But food is scarce, we're hungry, we all know we'll have to do... something.... soon.    And I am dreading it.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
												I will make this review as short as possible, with as little spoilers as possible. This is one of the greatest games I have ever played and it is one I hope is expanded upon with either DLC, content patches or sequels. This War of Mine is deceptively simplistic to play, yet under the hood is a very detailed, deep and moving game about the horrific consequences of war. The hand drawn look of the game, creates a bleak looking visual interpretation of a war torn world where colour is devoid, as is the love for life for the protagonists. The player is set to make countless life or death decisions for a handful of people who need to be guided through a month or two of what seems to be a civil war in a fictional Eastern Europe style city.  I don't normally play platform type games, especially ones that look like Snakes and Ladders but after only an hour or two of playing - I found my decision to purchase the game was completely worth while.You can play this game quite easily with just the mouse and it is easy to pick up and play. It took me about 16 hours to finish the game and did so without any guides or cheats, nor did I watch any "Lets Play's" on YouTube, and in itself made the experience even more rewarding. The story while not so deep (ie not very story rich) is still very moving, and one can easily become attached to the people you will be controlling.The game on occasion reminded me of SIMS, in which you control a persons needs and had a small resemblence to tower defense games or something along the lines of Civilisation where you build, upgrade and defend a base.While playing the game, I did not encounter any bugs or crashes and the only issue I met was in terms of game play mechanics. I found that I really did not need to upgrade many househole items and instead I decided to hoard materials to trade for food or save stacks of items I could burn, ready for when winter came along.The game could have lasted longer and had more story - and thus would have required me upgrading certain aspects of my base - but alas I did not need to as the game did not demand it. The game could have had a DLC with different story lines, such as maybe an alien invasion or a zombie apocalypse and of course I would not rule it out happening in the future, and I will be keenly watching an eye on developer news. This is a testament to the game's success, as I rarely keep an eye on specific developer releases once I have finished a game.At the end of the day, this was a very addictive game - and easy to pick up and play. I was left with a bittersweet feeling when the game ended for me after 46 days. I was happy that I managed to *win* the game on my first try - but I was quite sad because my daily dose of war was over; Quite ironic if you think of it.I look forward to more games from this developer and hopefully an expansion to this game. I also think if this game allowed mods via the Steam workshop - the games content could be expanded by it's own players giving this game a much longer shelf time.I give this game a solid A+ or a 9/10. If you are unsure as to whether to purchase this game or not, trust me that you will not be disappointed.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												This game really is a masterpiece and if I had a top 10 list of 2014 while this wouldn't be number 1 it would be pretty close. PROS:This game is stylized and I personally liked the look of the game  however I could understand if some were turned away by the black and white cell shading, I like it even more because it captures the atmosphere of the game which is dark and depressing. If you are looking for an uplifting game, don't look here. Completing this game will generally mean you get some blood on your hands, whether it is innocent blood or a bandit's is up to you. The gameplay is very nice as well, you have to be very vigilant in managing your finite supplies of food, water, and other materials used for building different additions onto your base. This management is difficult to learn what will be optimal for your survival, however once you achieve a good understanding of mechanics it is extremely satisfying to master, thriving in the war torn hell. There is also a randomized element in the game from random people coming to your door to offer you jobs or to ask for your help. This brings up your morals as some of the jobs you're asked to do might be....well let's just say nefarious in nature and it's completely up to you which tasks you spend your limited time completing. From multiple playthroughs I've seen different loot spawn in different places so that is also randomized to an extent making for even more replay value. There are also many different characters present in game that can show up to your door and join your group, all with different backstories, attitudes, and each have unique abilities that will help you in  your fight for survival. For the most part the looting and combat is intense and interesting. You can choose to stealthily creepy around buildings looting or go in guns blazing (if you manage to aquire a gun) the choice is yours on how you want to play the game. CONS:The soundtrack isn't very good, in fact there might not be one present in game as the only music I recall is when you tune your radio into different music stations. Combat/looting also has some quirks, nothing horrible but sometimes when you stealth kill an enemy others across the map will seemingly hear it and come rushing towards your position, this only happened to me twice in my gametime so it's not frequent but it definitely can happen. The characters in game are also not very interesting, each has his/her own backstory and if you pass an event their biography will update with their feelings on the situation. I personally didn't get very attached to any of them and when one died I was more concerned about who was going to go crawling through the dirt for food rather than sad about their passing, even a simple re-naming system for the characters would heighten my caring for their lives. VERDICT:I whole heartedly recommend this game as a fan of management, building, and looting games. If you purchase this game however beware that this isn't an easy experience and you most likely won't beat the game your first, or even second playthroughs. If you do manage to beat the game quickly not only are you better than me but the game has enough replay value where more runs are also very entertaining. I'm not much for number value reviews so I'll just say this game is definately worth adding to your library.

Intense and deeply involving.Pros:★ Gets you thinking.★ Great back story to this survival game.★ Shines in its ability to have the player make hard decisions.★ Every run through is different from the last.Cons:✖ Would have been better with more locations on the main map.✖ Could have had more Initial starting locations for each new game.This game will have you emotionally involved from the get go as you are faced with a few civilians who are trying to survive a war. You are faced with living off food scraps and low supplies of water to survive while trying to maintain your own health and sanity. Do you screw others over so you have a better chance of surviving? Or do you help those in the community but by detrimenting your own life? Without spoiling the game for you, you're faced with some very difficult decisions.As a side-scrolling indie thriller and with the specific tone the game sends out, this game won't be for everyone. But if you enjoy a choose-your-own-adventure style of gameplay and appreciate the subject of war you'll be hard to say no to This War of Mine.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2015
This War of Mine explores the harrowing realities of living amid war.Its resource management, life-sim and exploration mechanics are simple. Each day plays out in two phases. The clean split between day and night creates the steady metronome that keeps you pushing through This War of Mine. You're tasked with feeding survivors, ensuring they get a good night's rest and looking out for their physical as well as mental health.Systems This War of Mine's are designed to push you towards moral quandaries, where you're trapped by basic human needs, and shown how they can so easily corrupt otherwise upstanding people.Like a grim version of The Sims, players click around to move characters and on icons to assign tasks such as making food, building, clearing rubble, rifling through resource points or administering aid—either medicinal or moral. All of this is reliant on having the appropriate resources, which are gathered at night when a character can be sent to scavenge while the others sleep or stand guard. Locations include abandoned squallers, schools, hospitals, churches and more. Areas with more valuable resources are either inhabited or defended, while the safer places yield less.Everything outside line of sight is enveloped in a fog, giving the exploration real tension. Walking is silent but slow, while running comes at the risk of making noise, denoted by emanating circles of sound. Enemies emit these same tells, as do rats scurrying around. NPCs that hear the sounds or spot you in their line of sight will investigate, The defenseless cower, some propose a barter, others respond with deadly force. The slow, deliberate pacing accentuates the languishing, oppressive atmosphere.This War of Mine is one the most thematically interesting games.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2014
												I started with four people and made it to the ceasefire with all four of them alive, but only after spending 20 hours of non-stop mass deaths on every playthrough. This game has excellent art direction and sense of place; you KNOW after spending a week in-game that the city is a horrible place to live in. The day-to-day resource management is appropriately challenging; choosing to build an herb workshop rather than a rat trap could mean that no one in your house will make it to the end. Needs an optional tutorial though. I understand the developers' intention to show that you are a band of desperate people trying to figure things out, but I feel they should at least have something for people who are totally new to simulation/stealth games.However, I found myself being very engaged with the day-to-day struggles, and even now I am going back into the game to see if I can get another group of survivors to make it through the siege. I hope that there will be Steam Workshop support in the future, as I can see a lot of possibilities with the world of This War of Mine: Endless Mode, tweaks to traits,  maybe even new survivors. I strongly recommend this game to people who are willing to try a war game where no matter what you do, you can't stop the war yourself, and instead you're just trying to live long enough to see the end of it.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
												This game confronts the player with the harsh realities of war. The player plays from the perspective of a group of civilians in a fictional war-torn city, trying all that they can to survive in the difficult circumstances, holding on until 'the end'.There is a mixture of assertive and reactive elements (due to RNG) to this game, there is also a sufficient number of avenues for players to explore within. The 2D layout and the arcade-styled movement within makes it quite engaging. This game does however, suffer from the lack of significant replayability after two or three successful playthroughs.Nevertheless, it provides a poignant reminder of the effects of war, done very well within the confines of a game. It is highly recommended.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												Too often in games I can be cold and very heartless. I relish being the 'bad guy' in a lot of games, often opting for the 'easy choice' of choosing the mentality of 'the needs of one, outweighs the needs of the many'. I wanted a new challenge and perhaps something that could change my 'evil persona' in games... and boy, do I get a challenge with this game.This War of Mine is in a word; Brilliant. It's art style is very monochromatic, dark and pencil drawn, something which compliments the game's overall feel and direction. The musical score works really well with certain types of situations and often helps set the mood of a wore torn country that had clearly seen better days.But for me, while all of the details are important in the art style and music, the real impact this game has had on me is it's core mechanic; it's game play. Too often in modern games, players are not confronted with tough choices. When there are choices in games, they are often very clean and cut (do this and this will happen, don't and it won't - etc). I feel that because of this, players are not given the true consequences of their actions in games therefore making it much easier for players to turn 'bad' and reap the rewards. For me this is often why I went rogue. In This War of Mine, I simply cannot do it and when I have to, I feel terrible about it.Taking charge of a group of three survivors in a worn torn city who have shacked up in a abandoned building, the player is immediately confronted with a wide selection of problems right from the offset. One of your group may be sick, hungry, sad or simply tired and it is up to you to provide the fulfillment of their most basic needs in order to keep them alive. Sure, you can scavenge for stuff in your own dwelling but the resources found there will only get you so far so you must find additional materials/food from other areas around the city. Venturing into the city gives you no promises and it thrusts you into situations that make you question your morality. An example can be that you have a sick friend back at your shelter and you have gone into a home that you know has an elderly couple inside, one of which is very ill. Do you take their medical supplies to save your friend and risk destroying the morale of your group (because you stole from people who truly needed the supplies), or do you leave them be and potentially lose your party member, which in turn could create the same amount of dismay within the group? Other examples can simply come from making a bad call, i.e. getting your scavenger into situations that they went prepared for and killed, not returning back to the safety of your 'home' in time before the sun came up, or choosing to take additional survivors into the group whom of which you couldn't really provide enough resources to cover their basic needs.Because of the choices that you have to make and the knock-on results that they can bring, you pay the consequences or enjoy the rewards of your choices. Personally, it's refreshing to play a game that questions morality and adequately changes the gaming dynamic because of these calls.  This War of Mine gave me that new challenge in the choices that I make in games. I no longer wish to be the bad guy and when I do it in this game, it's not without reason. I really recommend this game to players of fifteen years older or more.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												This War of Mine is my new answer to the question, "Are Video Games a Legitimate Art Form?" In This War of Mine, you play an every day group of survivors, making tough, brutal decisions on how to survive. Battling sickness, injuries, looters, and the ever looming threat of death, your main goal in each of the Day/Night phases is making it just one more day.Good: EXTREMELY atmospheric. The visuals, music, and even the UI evokes a sense of desperation and despair. The characters just FEEL real. Their daily diaries do a good job of putting you in the shoes of desperate survivors. The choices in this game, the ones that hit you in the gut, are all natural and emergent. There's never a popup asking you if you want to steal for survival, there's just an unarmed old man asking, "Why are you doing this?" while you take meat for your two friends who haven't eaten in two days. The art style is... just beautiful. With the gameplay in "This War of Mine", they could have easily settled with 2D graphics, but instead they created a moving and engrossing setting with very real feeling characters. I LOVE 2D games, don't get me wrong, but I felt their treatment of the set pieces in this story really added to the experience for me.Bad: Sometimes the characters are a little hard to control. I found myself unable to make one of my characters do something for an entire day. Only happened once though, and that's about all I have to say negatively about this game.Ugly: War.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												A depressing, heart-wrenching reminder of what man is capable of doing to his fellow man in times of utmost necessity.Would you stick by your principles and morals whilst all around you abandoned theirs? Would you refuse to steal, or to kill? Would you stand by your guns and remain steadfast in your morality, your humanity, even whilst your family are freezing; starving; dying of disease? Many wouldn't.I didn't.And that, I believe, is the true value of this game. It made me think, a lot more than any other game I've recently played. It made me sit down and think about what I was doing, and why I was doing it.And it made me realise something:These characters, these people represented by pixels on a screen, could be any one of us, given all the wrong circumstances. With that knowledge also comes the understanding that, at some point in time, in some oft-forgotten conflict, a real human being decided they had no choice but to do exactly what you just did.That broke me, personally, for a while.It's depressing, it's soul-crushing, and yet it's somehow still so compelling.It's us, as a species, trying to survive the torture that we create for ourselves.War is hell.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
												One of my favorite games this year, much more than I expected it to be. This War of Mine is not simply Papers, Please thrust into a crafting/scavenging game. Instead, This War of Mine does a phenomenal job of conveying the desperate situation civilians find themselves when in the middle of a war zone. Every scavenging decision feels like a gamble. Address short-term needs or long-term investments? Steal from the elderly? Kill? Managing and crafting in your home shelter a continuous process of managing losses. Do you use the wood for fuel to stave off the cold, or do you board up your walls to protect against bandits? Can we really spare the last of our meds on an old man who will probably die anyway? Combat is messy, often unexpected, and traumatizing. You will not encounter very many fail-states in this game, as that would be contrary to the theme of desperate survival. What you will face is a slow march of ever worsening conditions, with the dim, almost non-existant hope, that a cease-fire will be signed to end all of soon and bring the game to 'victory'.In the mean time; however, two of my survivors have died, the remaining two are depressed and are coming to blows, and I only have enough food for one of them today. Who do I feed?

content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
												This game is a masterpiece. worth every penny I spent on it and I have played only few hours.The randomized scenarios, moral dilemmas and some hard choices that you will need to make and that will determinate if your survivors will pass out or if they will live another hard day, make this game one of the best games of 2014.Of course there are some points that could be better, such as the possibility of using more scavengers during the night or even a co-op (something like the inminent Don't Starve together) could be awesome. But in general terms you are paying for a fully enjoyable game here.Anyway, if you are wondering what game to buy due to the lack of new good/original games and you don't mind to play a single player game, you should go straight for this one.The last thing that you should know is that this is more likely a "hardcore" game -I prefer to call it "oldschool"-, with that I mean that there are no tutorials or helps of any kind. Only simplified descriptions of every item/tool, so you will need to find out how everything works. In fact, the methods are pretty simple, but you will maybe die trying somehow, but hey! remember that this is what the game is about.

content:
Posted: September 16, 2016
												Simple but fun survival mechanics. Multiple play throughs are a thing. I've only completed one full play through and I got the poor girls daddy killed because I was still not used to the stealth / path finding mechanics. That was my 3rd attempt at completing a play through because when one first starts this game - they will want to restart every time you get someone killed. But after you realize it's a story about the gruesome reality of war then you can move on and keep surviving with the rest of the members of your group. When I first got someone killed on my first two play throughs I restarted each time. One because you feel as if you lost an actual human being with a heart and sole. Second of all because this game gives you no tutorial on the combat mechanics. So it can be frustrating when you're trying to test them out when you first start. After you realize that the mechanics are very simple then you get used to it really really fast.      Enjoy the survival mechanics of the game during the day and then each night you can pick and choose who you want to stay at your shelter to guard or sleep. You can also choose to bring someone out for a scavange. This is where the action/stealth mechanics come into play. Very simple system with a simple point and click style. Simple, effective and fun. Very entertaining. I see now why this game won cultural awards. This game will pull at your heart strings. It tells a story. You're meant to pay attention to the small instances of story that pop up. Writing on the walls, photographs that capture the events of your play through. Even small bits of ones journal as well as the interactions you have with one another as well as other survivors in different areas that you can trade with. Watch out for thugs. They WILL put a bullet in you and you WILL lose one of your characters especially when you first start because you will feel the urge to test the mechanics out. Also, be careful where you click because sometimes your guys will decide to take a path straight into a bunch of armed thugs if you're not careful.    This game is dark and depressing. But in a beautiful way and I am still excited to play through several more play throughs because there are several areas that I still have not even chosen to explore yet. The game also gives you different scenarios to choose from and each one is unique in different ways 24 hours so far and I'm going to take a break now. This is definitely a game that I will periodically come back to and play.     This game will make you teary eyed. If you have a soul.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2016
												I've had this game for a while and I still love it, which can't be said for a lot of games.Not only are the visuals aesthetially pleasing, they also fit the theme of the game really well. Every single time I play, I go through every single emotion imaginable. The way individual events play with your heart and how each character has their own storyline and what makes it even better is that at the end, it's not an immediate cut off; you're told what happens to them after the ceasefire. This game is one of the most dramatic, exciting and heart wrenching games on the market and is worth every penny. Not only that, there's an additional DLC that you can buy which adds artwork to the game and the money goes to charity (you can also decide how much you spend, to a certain extent).However, there are a few things that I would like to see improved in the future as I believe it was touched on but not competely developed. Each character has a certain personality, explained in their biography. When certain events happen, their biography is updated with how they feel about the situation that happened, for example, if you choose to kill an NPC for supplies, some don't care while others actually do. What bothers me is that even though certain characters aren't affected by these, they still become sad, depressed and broken, leaving them completely useless. I would expect a character that actually understands the concept of self defense and the fact that sometimes we must kill for supplies and even says that they understand it, to not become so depressed. Another thing is during the day, sometimes there are events in which a survivor has the choice to leave the base and help an NPC out. It would be nice to add another choice to go with them, perhaps for an extra reward where you can physically help them out, such as clearing rubble, fixing up a base, healing people etc. (You could see it as a minigame during the day).All in all, I really recommend this game and I believe there is also room for improvement. If you're even thinking about it, buy it. You will not regret the decision and the replayability immense, with the difficulty changing every single time.

												Even though I haven't played it long, I've already done things in the game I didn't think I would do. Stealing and murdering - yeah sure - but to the people you do it? Just to survive? It got completely dark. A true survival game. Not to show of heroes but the victims. Victims of war. It's happening right now. When you go to sleep. It's happening. Game is brilliant. The atmospehere. The decision based choices. Live or die. You decide.Get this game with the DLC as the proceeds go to the War Child funds. Even if you're not in a war, help someone who is.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 19, 2014
												Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥ This is what being an Indie Dev is all about. They pushed the boundary of storytelling and presented a game that is full of the most depressing narrative I have ever played. If there is only one game this year you want to purchase, ditch every AAA title and go here. This War of Mine is gritty, dark, and one of the most imaginative games I've seen in awhile. It will push you to the brink of depression without reminding you that its just a game and to not worry about it. First play through I made it to Day 16. In the last couple of days my team went through numerous raids, sustained life threatening wounds, and fended off severe illnesses. On day 13, I ran out of food and decided to raid a home inhabited by an elderly couple that I knew couldn't defend themselves, I took everything I needed and they started calling for help. I decided that the risk of whatever may happen if help arrived wasn't worth the reward or their lives so I did them in. I took everything they had. I watched as my survivors sunk into deep depression about what they had did just for a nights meal. The next 3 days were filled with a downhill ride of depression, death, and abandonment. Much as I imagine what any person put in that situation would go through. This isn't just a game, it's an emotional trainwreck.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
												This is one of the best games I have ever played. It's not fun. It won't make you happy. In fact, it might make you miserable. Though you can meet the win conditions and manage to outlive the conflict it never feels like victory. Every action taken for survival must be weighed against the ultimate consequences for your crew.Yes there are puzzle aspects, and a good gamer will find ways to maximize their chances of survival. But ultimately this game forces you to make terrible choices, and manages to make you feel their consequences. This is the type of game that students should be playing in school as it manages to communicate some of the horrors experienced by non combatants in war.Buy it. Play it. Remember it.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												While I'm not normally fond of side scrollers This War of Mine is a rare exception. You play as a group of civilians held up in a run down old house in the middle of a war zone (civil war to be exact). How will you survive? Go out at night and find those must needed meds, or food. Trade with others barely holding on? or will you just take what you want.This game will have you choosing between letting your people die or gunning down that kid and his elderly parents for a couple of cans of food and maybe, a bottle of meds. All the while praying your base doesn't get raided and those people you are now murdering a small family for, are not killed.For those that don't like to look at the meaning behind their actions (in a video game) or the story you'd best not get this. Everyone else will see this game for what it is, a hard, soul-crushingly depressing, remorseless look at the horrors of war that'll have you playing just to see your guys though this hell hole until a cease fire is finally announced (picked at random).Those that are sensitive to emotionally taxing experiences may want to also avoid this game, at times you may be given the choice to help that woman being dragged off by an armed soldier, that main lying in the middle of the path with a sniper edging closer, and closer to you, or if killing that elderly couple is worth saving three lives.While this game is a side scroller it more then makes up for it in the meaning behind every action you take, and the consequences. If I had to give it a score? 9/10 and it only loses 1 because I had to kill a kid with my rifle to stop my group from starving. :(~ Edit for Steam Awards =P

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 11, 2015
												I've put many hours into this game and still find it fun with many more hours of replayability! <3This game is fun if you enjoy survival games where you have to manage surviors and resources and at times get slapped in the butt.Pros:Perfect balance of growing in strenght with the overcoming challangesEye-candy graphicsPerfect atmosphereHours and hours of funSemi-intresting charactersHard to master but easy to get in toFeels rewardingCons: Exiting the game during the night run will revert you back to the beginning of the day, so any changes in your shelter/surviors will have to be repeated.Non-stealth combat pretty much suicide/not an option even if you have the best gear due to how painful it is to recover if you do survive.Combat is a "roll the dice" chance of hitting the enemy unless you do a hidden takedown. Doing a backstab will take enemies to 20% health but due to how random it is, they can still kill or wound you in which case press alt + F4 and restart the day/night.Survivors are emotional timebombs waiting to go off the second you steal or kill someone however these is currently a glitch where returning to a dead thug's location after dealing with them(which is good karma) to loot the place may count as "stealing from innocent" even though that should not be the case. Doing more bad deeds will result in the surviors killing themself if you cannot keep them happy with various supplies(coffee, booze and cigarettes).In alot of cases looking up a location on the wiki before going there will save your life, in a sense... though you will get punished if you dont (with no knowlage of the place).Each surivor has a specific trait which will help you..... however in some cases they can be very useless or critical to you. An example of this is Roman who is trained in combat and can instantly take down someone from a backstab and pretty much kill one shot with a shotgun which makes him one of the best survivors. A good example of a bad one is Anton who has the trait "Good Mathematician" which does nothing. However each survivor you get is random over the campain but you can quit the game and press continue to get a diffrent survivor when one does arrive.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2016
												Time to stop playing FPS for a moment and think about its consequences.Personal point of view, you can surely ingore that if you want. When you point at a soldier's head in a game, will you think about his life? His lover? What will happen to his friends & relatives after you shot him? What will happen to his little girl, his greatest treasure that he want to protect to death? No, you would just think,"Oh another headshot, I'm doing fine." Real life is always not fun. BUT that is NOT the reason you vote for war & protest in a referendum. whe you just think that fighting is "fun". "Oh war is fine we like shooting each other in the face we are the youth we can protest what we against we don't afraid the consequence". I was totally terrified when I imagined what our children will be when they grew up in a peace world with bunch of great war games that told them how to fight/shoot against each other. Yes the war can never ends. but what if we show the consequence before our chilren can start the next war?That's why I like this game so much. It did what other FPS & war games can never do.Buy this product in any worth.Honestly, when you see a bunch of developer/publisher that the purpose of the game was not to impress people. but to save innocent children from war, you should definitly buy his product.Not for your consciences, but for their bravery & determination from doing that.11/10 Best anti-war game for so long.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 16, 2014
												Truly, what an amazing game this is! I've been sucked in for well over 12 hours in one sitting, something that very rarily happens for me with an indie game like this. (The play-time counter is broken for some reason...) The soundtrack is really good, it perfectly illustrates the doubt and fear in this group of survivors you're trying to lead. The gritty art style is very, very nicely done. The sketchy look and dull, grey colors do a really good job of showing this ravaged urban area. The stealth system is quite advanced, and the combat is random and really nervewracking (Think of XCOM). Losing a beloved member of the group is really a deep pain, and it echoes throughout the group. They mourn their dead and might even become depressed. The looting is very rewarding, and the limited inventory space forces heavy inventory management. Nothing like sneaking through a bandit camp and stealing all the goods that they themselves have stolen from others. The trading is very fun and well done, and it forces a lot of tough decisions. Do I want tobacco/alcohol that I may be able to sell for a good amount of food/materials, or do I want to just bring a smaller amount of materials or food and avoid the risk of not being able to sell it when I need food the most? The decisions you have to make are tough. I found myself robbing an elderly couple in pure desperation, only to stop for a moment and realize what I'd just done. The game has good replayability to a point, as it's somewhat randomized.All in all, one of the best, if not very best, survival indie games I have ever played. 10/10, would starve to death again.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 7, 2015
												So much has already been written about this game. I honestly don't know from where to start. The game provides you a glimpse of how people in real-world, when faced with War & brutality at its worst, survive. You live and breathe with these people everyday. Making preparations, saving resources that could enable you to survive another day. However, you're forced to scavenge for supplies, and that's where the real hard part comes in. You're forced to steal from people who really need it. People like the elderly couple, the sick people in the hospital, a son looking after his old parents, a wounded man trying to find his way back home to his infant boy. All these things, pull at your heart strings in ways I've never experienced in any game before. Perhaps, it would make people understand that the situation in Syria, the biggest humanitarian crisis since World War II, is something that shouldn't have happened in the first place. Unless we learn to get along with each other and come to terms with how we live our life, wars will continue to happen.Live & let live....Peace....

content:
Posted: November 16, 2014
												One of the best Resource Management/Survival game out there right nowYou start out with three random survivors (I got Bruno the cook, Katia the depression queen, and a random dude either pavle the runner or Marko  with 15 slot back pack).Basically you have to survive and struggle during a massive war between the gov't soldier and the rebels. To survive you have to scavenge nearby areas for food, materials and weapons.With limited resources, you have to make a choice whether who gets to eat Bruno's delicious stews, medicines and the guitar solo. You also able to make your own supplies like moonshining, growing "herbs", collecting rainwater/snow, trapping rodents and making cigarettes. If you upgrade your workshop enough, you could make armors, ammo and guns. When killing either a bandits or old people, Remember your survivors have FEELINGS. they will FEEL bad especially Katia, actually DON'T let Katia kill people ever.   Because what happens they get depressed, if they get depressed too long they will commit sudoku Overall 10/10 Would trade moonshines again

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2014
												The first thing we think about "war" game, of course it's action, explosions, etc. But now we have a game which make us  think about this type of games Now we are not soldiers with best equipment and supplies, we are ordinary people. This game isn't about war itself, it's about people trying to live during it, trying to get everything need like shelter, food or medcine. This game make you empathize characters and people you meet, but that doesn't mean everyone is kind , the main danger during time like this are people, this is the first thing you have to be careful with, otherwise everything can turn sad. "This War of Mine" make us think what will we do if something like that happens to us, how to plan your surviving tactic,  how not to die in this world of war.Platformer style really fits gameplay, it's really interesting to watch and play like that. Gameplay is good, it's comfortable and nice to play this game, controls are simple and easy to learn. But in my opinion there some problems with stealth and other trivia, by the way that doesn't spoil the experience of playing. Developers made huge achievment, they showed us that there is something special left, that you can make small, but in the same time something huge, that's risky step, but they did great work.

Started yesterday, finished today :Dthis game had me at "hello" ;) im not sure if its my favorite or my least favorite game though... its the first game that has me kinda melancholic even after i survived - which gamewise should be a success. I think I have a more insightful view of war now than I had before. That being said I never supported war in the first place, however now i can relate to the victims even more (i think). So + atmosphere (music, sounds, graphics) seemed perfect to me , goal of the game itself (besides making money for the people creating it) was amazingly accomplished = to show what war is like for civilians, if i gave it more thought i could probably come up with more positives since I cant think of anything negative gameplaywise- gametime (as i said, started yesterday afternoon, finished today), even though that might be a good thing, since any more time playing it might have had me depressed for a longer time,no explanation as it comes to e.g. how to turn ice into water (ingame, not real life (that one i can figure out))  - then again the civilians don't have any guides either as it comes to surviving.The price might be a little high, for that little gametime. 10 - 15 € would have been more reasonable but whatever.Thats the best criticism I could come up with. I loved the game!! Or hated it!! I dont know! At least i have strong feelings towards it!! :D

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
												I bought this game last night, pretty much sight-unseen. It was then suddenly four in the morning.I'm not sure how much credibility a review written after five hours of gameplay can hold, but I thought the first sentence probably covers whether or not I'd recommend it.In terms of actual reviewy type things, I can tell you this:The gameplay is excellent, filled with the tension you'd expect to experience living in a besieged city. This atmosphere is executed brilliantly, the art style, music and pacing all lending more to it, allowing you to really put yourself into the space presented to you with your poor, semi-displaced trio of housemates.I've played a lot of survival games and all of them have one conceit or another to explain the situation (zombies, spiders, zombies, aliens, zombies etc.) but the more realistic story in This War of Mine (a story being played out in the world in a number of places right now), in my opinion, lends it a more visceral, wholly real, experience.If you're a fan of the survival genre, or a fan of artistic, atmospheric games, I'd suggest that you will not regret handing over your money for this one.

												Damn good, and super immersive.  My 1st session lasted a lot longer than I thought it would.  Finding a balance between risk vs reward is a huge part of this game, and there's always been a sense of tension while I was playing; whether it was because we were only finding scraps of food when everyone was hungry, or when a gunman is lurking just around the corner of where you are looting. There's a lot of choices but no fast paced action, but it's probably more intense than all the Call of Duty's put together.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
												This War of Mine could be called the offspring of DayZ and XCOM: Enemy Unknown (whose older sister was The Sims), both excellent games that are strategic, tense and merciless. But beyond that, nearly all simularities end, unless you play This War of Mine.This aptly named title, is a 2D survival game where you control a group of survivors, holed up in a shabby cottage-like structure, trying to ignore the horrors of the war going on outside and focus on living.Your first (in-game) day is essentially getting your cottage ready, you will need to get rid of rubble, grab all the supplies still within, and create furniture for your home. Sounds kinda like the Sims, right? Yeah, well, throw the idea of not letting your Sims eat food out the window now, because it gets merciless from here.The night (much like most survival games) is where the true danger is at. You are going to exhaust your supplies pretty quickly unless you go out scavenging, so it is essential you go out and collect more supplies. This is where night comes in. At night, you want to select what your party is going to be doing for the remainder of the night. Do they guard, sleep, sleep in beds, or scavenge? I generally had 1 guarding, 1-2 sleeping on beds (you have to make the beds, so don't expect them to be happy if you don't have them) and 1 scavenging. The person you have got scavenging is the only person you will control for the rest of the night.You select the site in which your scavenger will... scavenge. He/she will be controlled by you for the remainder of the night. Considering it is your first night, chances are, you have no weapons, no lockpicks, nothing. Just you, your wits and your stealth ability.You start to enter the house, slowly creeping around to make sure no one that might be in the house hears you.You scrounge around in a few cupboards, not a lot. That's when you see it: The icon that shows a hand reaching for a diamond. Do you want to take from private property? Do you want to take from people? Do you want to become a bandit? You take it, feeling guilty for your actions, and continue on.You make it back only just in time, before dawn so you could get home without a Sniper seeing you.Then, as if last night wasn't stressful enough: You've been raided. Your guard is wounded.You now have to take the time to nurse to him, sort your supplies, build all the things you need and countless other things. You start doing your work when you hear a knock on the door.A kid wants your help, he has no more medicine to tend to his mother and pleads for your help.It is up to you to decide all these moral choices, but there will always be a consequence for your actions. You may have done the right thing, but you lost some valuable supplies. You turned them down because you need them, but now your survivors are doubting their situation.I may have described the typical night, but you still need to address your teams morale, cook food, and so on. Actions such as killing people and stealing from helpless affect your team's emotions, sometimes causing PTSD. It is good to see a game take killing so seriously, it isn't done too often. Their emotions can cause them to degrade others, stop being motivated in doing their tasks, and even making them leave your group. It is something you always need to think about before taking action.Time moves interestingly in this game. Time will move 10 minutes about every 15 or so seconds. Once it reaches 8 PM, it transits into your night duties. During the night, you need to get out of there by 4:30 AM, otherwise you may not make it back. You can end both day and night early if you feel that you will be wasting time waiting. But time is of essence and you must use it wisely for your survival.The art-style consists of very little colour, with a lot of pencil detail. While it does a good job at setting the dreary mood, I did think it could have been a bit more lush and vibrant, and it can get a little straining on the eyes. Although it has good icons and controls so you get the hang of it pretty quickly, This War of Mine does lack a strong tutorial. While something can be said of realism and throwing you in the deep-end, I do feel that some people might struggle initially. It is rather hard to describe this game, because it's a game that is rather new in concept, a rather surprising sight considering the recent popularity of survival games.Overall, I really enjoyed this game, everything is thought out and all the ideas have been well executed on. It could do with some improvements, but this game does a fantastic job at showing the horrors of war in an engaging way, while also proving to still have solid game mechanics. It is a must buy for any fan of the survivalist/war-story genres.8.5 out of 10.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												UPDATE: With the new editor, this game can also double as Baltimore Simulator 2015. This game is basically Ukraine Simulator 2015.The Good:- There isn't really a tutorial, which helps to create an atmoshpere of caution as you play through the game. You get relatively few characters to use, each with their own benefit, so losing even one may have dire consequences.- The gameplay has the right amount of challenge to it. If you play smart, you should be alright but if you do not, you will not survive. The fact that the game is unforgiving also helps to evoke the sense of desperation present in the characters' situation.- The environment. With the right tools, you can begin to destroy things like cabinets to scavenge them for parts.- The art style. The way the game handles shading, and your characters' field of vision, is great.- The game evolves as you play. Did you leave a pile of wood in that rubble, for later? Getting back to it may suddenly become impossible, between the fighting and the snow. And if you do get back to it, there's no guarantee it'll even be there, if the area you're going has people at it. It makes the choice between that can of food, or that bunch of planks, all the more important.- Your characters give you feedback about the choices that they make, and their feedback can have tangible results in gameplay. Generally, the more horrible you are to your fellow man, the sadder your little group becomes, which seems to effect how quickly they move, or perform tasks.This game is very immersive. If you were a fan of the Fallout Series, but also enjoy a more "serious", even dark, atmosphere, this game is definitely for you.The Bad:- The game gets repetitious, during the day cycle. - "Realism". This War of Mine does a good job of drawing you into the setting, but at the same time there are a lot of little things that break one's suspension of disbelief. The way the game squishes time means that it can take your people a half an hour to climb two ladders and walk a hundred feet to answer the door. In a game focused on gathering and survival, there are a lot of things that you can't scavenge. Doors, and the planks barring the doors, I'm looking at you. Papercuts also generally don't require rolls of bandages to combat. And closing doors doesn't seem to increase the temperature in your shelter any, when it starts getting cold. Also, why I have to purify my water before I boil it, I'll never know.- The game's "Good choice/bad choice" moments are pretty generic "do the good and inconvenient thing/do the bad and helpful thing" survival choices. Where the decision making really begins to get murky, is with the internal choices such as "Who gets to eat?" (Sorry I let you starve Bruno, but the irony of the cook starving was too amusing).- The level of interaction you have with other people is limited in comparison to games with similar themes.- There is no tutorial. This is also in the Good category. This is also bad because the game does not explain how combat works, so the first few times a situation goes sideways you will probably lose due to figuring out what does what.This is a slower-paced game. If you are a fan of flashier/shooter games, and not a fan of micromanagement, this game probably isn't your cup of tea.All in all? I'd rate this game a solid 8.5/10.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												This is arguably the best zombie game ever made, despite the absence of zombies. It's an excellent wargame, despite the war happening in the background. It's an incredible resource management game, and it reflects both the tedium and the agonizing decision making that accompanies a desperate battle for survival without ever feeling heavy-handed.The narrative is almost entirely emergent, but this game nails its tone.Did it change the way I think about war? No, not really. But I found the experience genuinely compelling.

												I read a lot of good things about this game before I finally got to play it. And for once everybody was absolutely right!!It is totally absorbing in a way that's as entertaining as it is depressing.  Slowly you become more and more involved with the war victims in the game and although it is as desperate as it probably is in real life every little victory is immensely satisfying. I never managed to play beyond day 30 yet but somehow I keep restarting and giving it another try. Although the setting is much more harsh the game reminds me of Expedition Conquistadores at times. (making your choices of where to scavenge at night and doing all the necessary chores in daytime. Also the  involvement with your characters) This is one hell of a game and I'd strongly recommend it to anyone who likes a challenge in a somber but realisttic setting. There's a lot of choices but no fast paced action, but it's probably more intense than all the Call of Duty's put together.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
												This is a war game unlike any I've ever played. Instead of playing as a soldier on the frontlines, you're playing as a band of civilians trying to survive the war-torn city. You have to scavenge for food and supplies, craft essential things like beds and stoves, and even deal with other survivors. Keeping your survivors in check by feeding them, making sure they're well-rested and not sick, and keeping specialized ones (one survivor is a better scavenger, for example, while another is good at cooking) alive is no easy task. This game definitely shows the civilian side of war, doing whatever it takes to survive.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2016
												Amazing game, it's not mechanically difficult but rather it's difficulty lies in the choices you have to make in order to survive. Will you take food and medicine from an elderly couple who have no chance of surviving without it? If someone is begging for food will you give it to them or just let them starve? Will you kill a thug? what about a soldier? These are the kind of decisions you have to make and every one you make will affect your character(s). The atmosphere is heavy and the soundtrack is intense. In the hours I have played I think I only caught like 2 or 3 noticeable bugs so the developers definitely did a great job, I highly recommend it. Can't wait for Frostpunk!

real", it just makes it more tedious (imo thier actually just farming "hours played"though the game is fairly decent graphic and function wise, it couldve been morecause honestly, i cant imagine theres nothing to do (as a civ in a warzone)than set up stills and scavenge by night...actually and im sorry if im wrong, but if this is supposed to be a REAL protrayal of life in a warzone, then this game is probably doing a great disserviceits a war repressed life simulator, but even so, its really basic, theres a crap load of realisticstrategy and actions missing, though im sure they left out the more complex thinking for "sensitivity" since again, this is a life simulatorthough i dont prescribe to those notions, i understand why(theres a difference tween being tastefull, and "whitewashing", this is whitewashed)some realisim factors bother mei definatly wouldnt choose to set up in a 4 story buildingwould have more security than a reinforced door and "alarm" (if im looting, probably wont use the front door)any self respecting person would clean out the debris (safety, morale and you want the space)the idea that your catching mice to feed 3 people and only set up 2 trapswould not waste the resources to make my garden look like a hydroponic lab(frame in a few rows of dirt and be done) (and its more economic to expand 1 gardenthan to set up more)also i would hope that people with addictions like smoking or coffe wouldnt get depressedand kill themselves, to me that sounds like gross overstatment,you have way more to worry about,and again, i would hope that the overwhelming majority of people would get used to it(not suicide a few days later)and since im not purchasing the DLC, ill comment on that here,children are NOT useless, they can do everything in the game that adults can,though id supervise them making meds or ammo and wouldnt give them a shotgun or asault riflealso children adapt just like adults, (sometimes better) overtime child should numb up to the circumstances, not be in perpetual fear and depression, its the undoing of those affects that presents more challengesalso a child being worked shouldnt cause depression, often they take pride in thier ability to helpaddendum* in respose to comments, to kinda justify why i focused on "realisim"im on the fence, i cant be sure they intended to just float about the subjectand capitolize on peoples interestor they wanted to portray life as a civ in a warzonebut lacked the bagonias to actually go into itim the kind of person who sees "based/inspired by real events"and believes "in principal" it sould be a realistic accountingbecause if you dont hold it to standards...poke`mon is "inspired by real events"how is pet market supplied? people go out and capture animalsbreeding programs arnt in place for many pets(anything not cats or dogs) those that do (especialy dogs)have imbreeding issues (purebred = imbred ~70% of the time)if we look deep into that argumentthe difference tween pet ownership and pokemonis each owner didnt catch thier pet themselvescause right down to contests breeding and unfourtunate fightingdont only exist in pokemon, its real tooand while i understand its a silly comparisoni feel it does help make both points1, that the game is either, scraping the barrel for moneyor is purposely white-washing a rather serious issue2, that they should content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
												It was certainitly an interesting game, but I don't reccomend it because I swear it's trying way too hard to be edgy and depressing. For example, you kill ANYONE and the entire ♥♥♥♥ing team get depressed and starts questioning life and♥♥♥♥♥♥ I started my second playthrough, and was sneaking through a church and found this guy bragging about killing the priest who shelterd the sick and homeless during the war. The man was taking all of the church's stuff after killing everyone there, and when he spotted me tried to shoot me. So I stabbed the little♥♥♥♥♥♥to death. I take what I need, and go home. Hell, I even sparred another group of people a house over who ended up chasing after me with an AK-47, and when I had the chance to stab one, I decided to let them go. Then I get home and character is "depressed" and won't stop moaning about how ashamed she was of what she did. Come on, that's ridiculous. To make things worse, the rest of the team becomes sad. I can understand people getting sad when you steal from the elderly, but I genuinly can't engage even the most bloodthirsty tyrants without everyone getting sad. Stop trying to make me feel bad for killing murderers, because I don't feel bad about it. Additionally, the difficulty is fun at first, but just gets stupid at some points. It gets to the point where your people are getting sick and injured for no reason. I keep a furnace with kindling in it 24/7 to keep my place warm, yet everyone gets sick because of the cold 2/3 of my team ended up terminally ill as well. I put people on gaurd every night, and build defnses, yet we get raided every night. A hard game is fine, but a cheating game is not. If I can't counter these problems, why put them in and pretend I can counter them? An interesting idea, but it needs some polishing before I can reccomend it.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
This War Of Mine Game ini bener bener slow and mellow banget. Susananya sedih, putus asa, dan pelan banget membuat lo gak sadar bahwa lo udah menghabis 5 jam ++ ketika pertama kali main game ini. This War Of Mine bener bener membuka pandangan baru terhadap perang dan pengalaman yang jarang banget ada game lain. Kalau lo liat game lagi sale, lo musti beli.Score total = 8 dari 10 Storyline : 8 jam gue bermain dan kayanya sih gak ada storyline. Dari awal sampai akhir lo mempunyai kebebasan bagaimana caranya lo ingin survive. Walau pun begitu, disetiap karakter terdapat semacam background cerita kecil yang... kayanya nih yah... sama sekali gak mempunyai efek begitu besar didalam gameplay. Jadi, ya basically, lo bakalan memulai game dengan 3 orang karakter random dengan background ceritanya masing masing dan lo musti memanage ke 3 orang tersebut untuk survive.Display : Ini adalah game 3D side scrolling game. For some reason, elemen grafiknnya cukup kuat disini. So beberapa tempat yang lo bakalan datangi bakalan hancur. Jelas banget bekas peperangannya seperti lubang peluru, tembok hancur, atap rubuh, pintu di blokir, ban dibakar, gelap, grafiti dll. Efek yang paling menarik adalah efek pensil disetiap tembok. Seakan akan lo sedang 'menonton' sebuah lukisan. Animasi yang ditawarkan juga sederhana aja. Mulai dari default sampai combat keliatan mulus dan udah dipoles secara sempurna. Gue sampai sejauh ini gak menemukan bug atau glitch didalam game ini. Music : Jujur gue jarang banget membahas aspek musik didalam game tapi gue punya pengecualian dengan game ini. Perpaduan grafik dan musik ini membuat lo galau dan putus asa. Musiknya itu melow banget... Serius, musiknya berhasil menyedot gue kedalam game. Gue tuh rasanya baru main satu jam, tapi begitu gue nengok ke jam dinding, eh udah 8 jam aja. Ini baru satu kali main lho.. baru satu kali pencet tombol play di Steam. Gameplay : Survival, looting and crafting. Yup, tiga kalimat ini udah jelas banget ya. Misi utama lo adalah survival ditengah peperangan. Lo musti bertahan diri dari panggilan alam (lapar atau sakit), bandit, bahkan teman lo sendiri. Nah, untuk bisa memenuhi kebutuhan lo, mau gak mau lo musti looting. Pertama kali main, gak akan ada tutorial. Jadi lo langsung muncul dengan 3 orang karakter dan sama sekali gak tau musti apa yang dipencet atau apa yang di klik. Duh... Nah, ketika lo udah berkenalan dengan control, mulai deh. Hal yang pertama kali lo musti lakukan adalah looting markas lo sendiri. Lo bisa search di lemari, meja, dsb lah. Begitu udah cukup resource, segera buat workshoop dan toolshop. WAJIB BUAT SHOVEL DAN CROWBAR karena itu adalah 2 tools untuk looting. Setelah itu bebas deh mau buat apa.. ini review ya bukan tutorial jadi you figure it out lah.. okay balik maning, setelah lo looting dan crafting, lo musti cari resource lagi ditempat lain. Begitu end of the day, lo bakalan memanage tugas karakter lo. Satu disuruh jaga, satu disuruh tidur, satu disuruh scavenge ya itu terserah lo. Nah begitu lo menyuruh scavenge, gameplay bakalan masuk ke tempat lain dan tugas lo adalah looting. Ingat, lo cuman punya waktu 1 malam untuk looting. Lo musti pulang sebelum matahari terbit atau ada kemungkinan besar karakter lo mati. Begitu karakter lo kembali, do that crafting, cooking, sleeping and stuff.Kesimpulan : This War Of Mine adalah game bagus yang bener bener niat. Game ini menekankan gameplay sebagai senjata utamanya. Harganya juga masuk akal kok dengan fitur yang ditawarkan. Fair price. Kalau lo suka survival looting dan crafting dengan spek komputer standart, ya lo bisa coba lah game ini. Gue jamin, lo ikutan galau. Jujur, butuh tingkat pemikiran dan daya filosofi yang lumayan untuk main game ini.

number of helpful: 16 of 29 people (55%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 11, 2016
												This game really doesn't have much behind the shiny coat of paint it dons. Stripping it away reveals an overly simplistic inventory management game with rudimentary stealth and combat mechanics.And don't get me wrong, I love inventory management. But this game is bogged down by so many annoyances that add up, resulting in a game that is extremely tedious and boring to play. Some problems could've been avoided by adding a timer speed up, some could have been avoided with some balancing. Why do I have to watch a character dig a pile of rubble for two minutes and have nothing to do meanwhile? The shelter management is a joke, it could've probably been a text-based screen and it would've been much better. It is RIDICULOUSLY easy if you survive after the first few days. You will be drowning in expensive resources after you learn to prioritize what to loot. Trading is balanced poorly - why would you ever waste your time travelling to a trader when you can just scavenge meanwhile and sell/buy the junk you need from the trader that comes to your house every 3-4 days?And as much as the theme and atmosphere of this game is praised, most of it falls flat because of bad game mechanics, and the other times is just so obnoxiously ham-fisted. You can loot an elderly couples house of all food and medical supplies and replace it with wood blocks, yet they will somehow manage to live happily until the end of the war. The game just tells you to feel bad without actually showing anything happening due to your actions, save for a few rare exceptions.I can only recommend getting this during a sale, for a touch device preferably. Expecting an interesting narrative or captivating gameplay will leave you disappointed otherwise.
