content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
												I've played through this game a couple of times now and would absolutely recommend it to anyone who likes the survival genre. While the mechanics are similar to other games and there is no real exploration element it does set a very unique atmosphere. You are playing civilians who pretty much start out with nothing except some bits and pieces of parts and wood scattered around your compound. The game itself has a fairly steep learning curve but it is a short curve. You might fail once or twice. Those games are probably going to be more memorable than the successful ones as it hammers home the suffering in a war torn country.You can choose to be ruthless, brave or cautious. Should you choose the agressive path you will probably find the game easy, however the point is you need to invest yourself in the lives of ordinary people. When are you desperate enough to kill for survival?The DLC proceeds go to charity so do pick that up too!Only gripe I have with this game really is the save mechanic that saves at the beginning of the day and at no other time. Sometimes I would really have liked to save after the day ended as I do not always have the time to go through the night mission before logging off.Get it though, it is worth it!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												This game touches a subject that most games don't: the lives of civilians during war. And I have to say, it does the work brilliantly. You'll feel the bleakness of the atmosphere and the despair of your survivors. And more often than not you're forced to take meaningful moral choices: when you really need supplies, do you try to sneak around a warehouse full of patrolling bandits and risk getting shot, or do you barge in a small house owned by an elderly couple and rob them blind? Whatever you choose, the game won't blatantly tell you if you're right or wrong, but your characters (and you) will remember your actions.One of the best parts about this game is the survivors. Each of them has their own story and personality, so they feel like real, believable people instead of machines. You'll want them to survive, and you'll feel terrible if one of them dies for whatever reasons. In addition, the endings for your survivors are cleverly built in as well. Even when you've survived the war, you may find that you just haven't won at all, as your people fail to find their families and friends, live an unhappy life, or even commit suicide out of guilt. The moment when each of your characters earns their happy ending is the most heartwarming moment ever.Even when I've completely mastered this game, I still found myself coming back to it over and over again. I'm not exaggerating; this is a game that everyone should play at least once.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2015
This War Of Mine; Full ReviewThis War of Mine is a 2014 war survival video game developed by 11 bit studios. The game, which was inspired by the 1992–96 Siege of Sarajevo during the Bosnian War, differs from most war-themed video games by focusing on the civilian experience of war rather than frontline combat. This War of Mine was released for the Microsoft Windows, OS X and Linux operating systems in November 2014. Android and iOS versions were released in July 14, 2015. A PlayStation 4 and Xbox One release titled This War of Mine: The Little Ones has been announced for a January 29, 2016 release. This version features new missions and charactersThe game starts you off in a bombed house and you must improve it with barricades and fortifications, The game also allows you to add several items which may improve the state of the characters that are desprately trying to scrounge by.This game is in no way a light subject or a cheery game, because it focuses on the struggles of civillians inside the war, don't pick this game up if you are looking for a cheery lighthearted game because this isnt going to provide you with it, instead pick up this game if you are looking for a hardcore survival/sim game.The main objective of the game is to survive until the end of the war sometimes that time is quick sometimes not, either way scavenge for food, weapons, and materials to survive.PROS  Very fun Very hardcore simulation/survival game  Amazing art style  Not another stupid Zombie survival  Good crafting/building system  (this is a semi-pro) Very hard resource management  Good replayability  Different skills  There is morality and you can go insane  Nice atmosphereCONS  Gets boring after learned everything  Game gets tedious and repetitive  No speed upFINAL VERDICT87/100

												It's the love child of The Sims and Oregon Trail; however when my Sim was sad, it didn't tug at my heartstrings like this game manages to do. This brilliant strategy game has your survivors looting, crafting, combating, and bartering all while trying to manage their basic survival needs like sleep, health,  food, and comfort. The choices you make are important because some characters are better at cooking others at running. These characters have truly come to life because of how their actions may take a toll on their conscience. Realistic setting, great strategy, and sensitive subject matter tackled eloquently makes this game a high recommendation.

Posted: December 10, 2014
												Arica was killed by a man living in the bottom of St. Mary's church. The night prior she had killed a man toting a gun with a hatchet before he could shoot her down, and returned home to have a mental breakdown after finding out Rowan and Anton had a fight. Roman, being ex-militia, wanted revenge for her death, so he took up his axe and went to St. Mary's church. He knocked on the basement door, and when he saw the man who had killed her he struck him dead. Two women ran over to mourn over the man's dead body as Rowan trudged through the house, looking for valuables to take, but hearing the two women frightened and crying made him want to leave despite feeling completely justified in his murder. Arica's death sent my group into a downward spiral of despair and hopelessness until Roman finally built the garden Arica had been scavenging parts for for weeks. I like to think they call it "Arica's Garden", and at every meal they remember her sacrifice and bravery.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2016
												This game has been in my library for some time. I finished it twice and then left it. After seeing there has been a free anniversary update (how often do we see publishers do this?) I decided to take up the game again and am finishing it for the 4th time now. Each day is split in day and night.  Daylight is to dangerous to be outside in the war torn city so you will be repairing the house you live in, craft furniture, cigarettes, weapons or moonshine, cook, grow vegetables, take care of the wounded and sick and sleep without being scared of robbers.Night time one of your survivors can venture out in the city to scavenge for construction materials, food, medicines, help out people caught in the crossfire of the war while your other survivors need to choose between guarding the house against robbers or getting some sleep and healing wounds and or diseases.A small jewel of a game.Different characters with their pro´s and cons, different starting houses, different buildings and buildings setups and occupations make each replay unique.Music, artwork, colouring and stories give a grim view on people struggling to live through a war.Several ways of supporting NGO War Child through purchasing dlc´s Can absolutely recommend this game!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
This War of MineRecommended for those are into survival- simulation, time management and high replayability value.Note : I buy this recently, with the Anniversary Edition update included. TL;DR version  Items (Alphabetically) Score (1-3/3)   Control and Gameplay 3/3   Fun Factor 2/3   Graphic 2/3   Replayability Value 3/3   Sound 2/3   Story 2/3   Value for Full Price 2/3  LONG VERSION1. Control and Gameplay : point and click game, with some "panic system" at times. Minimum loading screen. Autosave system. Even at high res setting, it does not lag. Quite realistic and easy to learn. 2. Fun Factor : I am not quite amused by timed- management games, but it give me adequate times to think and act wisely. Will get used to quickly deciding actions in just a minute. 3. Graphic : Unique sketchy and black-and-white-ish artwork is really suited the gloomy and mellow war atmosphere. The small details is impressive, but limited variations on item designs.4. Replayability Value : you have custom mode stories and more content could be downloaded at workshop (the dev encourages it, they prepare a clickable link to workshop on start title). Nice bonus for adding a surprise free update/dlc after 3 years of release date (the anniversary mode- add new locations and npcs).5. Sound : nothing spectacular, but the music fits the theme well.6. Story : fresh point of view, quite uncommon to play as the victims (while usually we get used to FPS as the soldiers). Some stories, they require tissues while playing at it.7. Value for Full Price : to support the great indie developers out there, why not? But honestly, it's quite overpriced for college student like me. And also, I am interested to pay the dlc (which 10% of it is a charity) with the price gap in sale.Thank you for reading!

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
A true group survival simulator. No zombies, no T-viruses, no nonsense. It's worse. It's real.It's such a realistic survival experience, that you feel for your characters. You live as them and you help one another for real, in spite of self.It's like sims just much more brutal and emotional. A sim burnt by a stove? pfft. I did that on sunny sundays. "This War of Mine" is your harshest weekdays compared to that.Decisions decisions. You can play it heartlessly and egoistically when your pals are dying and your neighbours are too, but I dare you to delve into this atmospheric and grim game and not feel sympathetic. This is the war of yours. War of theirs.And watch out. The winter is coming...Upd.It only has become better with the addition of Anniversary edition mode and The Little Ones DLC.In a sum they add new locations (which are very welcome), new characters, new game mechanics, new NPCs, new setups. But what is REALLY new is KIDS.You got kids characters now in your party, sometimes paired with an adult, and it's a real party member, and it's a KID in a WAR... So you should care about them and you can also teach them to do and make things and they don't take separate beds. And of course they are not as useful as an adult in a party of 4 and they can't go on a scavenge run or defend shelter, in fact it's kind of a complication, as is often with kids in real life, to be honest, if to be seen purely practical.But we all know this game is about emotions, about realism and about decisions. So this again is a decision and it's only making this game a bit harder sometimes but also more interesting.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2015
												This war of mine is a fantastic game. It scratched all the itches that I had going into the game from the description. Oh and the DLC idea, amazing. For those of you who haven't seen yet or assume that it's only one part of the game that is all black and white, it's not. Don't let that discourage you though, the theme alongside the music for this game is perfectly suited and it adds a lot of atmosphere to the game. The whole game plays out as a cross sectional doll house style which works really well. You are not a solider or hero. Let me say that again, You are NOT a solider or hero. You will struggle, you will lose people along the way and you will despair at the constant dire situations you find yourself in. This game has done an amazing job portraying the struggle or regular people trapped in a war locked country trying to survive. Sure you can try and take people on using force to take what is theirs but you can also try to scavenge and stay morally and literally safe. This game throws a lot at you in the beginning and it does take a little while to get the hang of all aspects but even once you have (by the start of the third scenario I had the game figured out entirely) the game still offers a lot of challenge especially at the start. Balancing the need for food, security, warmth, sleep, preventing illness and injury as well as treating those issues is a constant for most of your game. Usually you are dealing with multiple issues at once while still trying to get your base up and running.I've had a lot of fun on this game, I picked it up for around $8 USD during a sale but honestly for me it felt worth the full price. The DLC for this game comes in three different prices that all do the same thing. It gives you an achievement, adds a bunch of graffiti art to previously available locations, these unlock an achievement once you have found them all. Most importantly of all though, all the money from DLC purchases goes entirely to the charity War Child. I couldn't believe it when I saw that, what an amazing idea to make achievements and the DLC go towards a good cause. I bought it and while most people don't care about achievements I'm proud to have both of these two because they do actually mean something for a change. A couple of little negatives to round up the review. Once you know how everything works the game gets easier, not entirely easy but a lot of the challenge and excitement of trying to figure out the game is gone because you follow a lot of the same principals to getting yourself established. When you have nothing to do in the base it can get a bit annoying to wait a minute or two for the day to end while you just sit there. You can click end day and move straight into the night but you could miss out on a potential visitor to your base by doing this. (1 per day max). The combat can be quite clunky and strange to get use to. Sometime you will encounter a few bugs but nothing game breaking, the worst I had was a random -5 degree day not during winter and 18 fuel for fire disappearing from my inventory. Overall I definitely got my money and times worth from this game, I recommend it strongly to anyone that this style of game appeals to even remotely. 8.5/10

content:
Posted: January 14
												During my school years i was going through the library when i stumbled upon a book called "i remember Beirut" by Zeina Abirached. it was a comic book about the authors childhood living in Lebanon during a civil war, which sadly goes on today. I never even heard of Lebanon and every person at school i talked to about it never heard of the country as well. I even attempted to talk about it in one of my history projects, but then i realized i couldn't and had to go on about Gallipoli that the school system thought was so ♥♥♥♥ing important to learn the third time. There are so many places in the world that are strife with war that should been talked about in the news, but the only countries the news wants to show are Jerusalem and Syria, which sadly many people might know the country because of the conflict."This war of mine" is a form of justice that the developers wanted to show to the world, about a subject that is not looked up to a lot in gaming, hell even most media. I always like my fast paced action games such as "F.E.A.R", and even sometimes implemented humor like "Postal 2". But sometimes you just have to come back to earth and look at the harsh realities of human nature that has gone haywire. Its a game that doesn't shy away from mature themes on war and even if it doesn't have a spectacular combat system it makes up for on how it's presented.gameplaythe controls of the game is fully mouse use and works well for the most part. you do everything with it, from moving to selecting to placing to attacking to all that sort of stuff. the reason for this could be for the fact you play as an entire group. you have two cycles, one where you manage your group and  you shelter in the day, and one where your desperately scavenge a selected location during the night.the day time cycle is when you have to manage your stats of your survivors and possibly improve your shelter, you can make various crafting stations and miscellaneous stuff such as chairs. sometimes people come to your shelter to exchange goods or to ask for help for possibly goods in return. Even the characters you have all have unique stats and personality. some like to smoke and others like coffee, you don't have to do their needs and their happy to help out. you only have a certain amount of time during the day and your constantly rushing to do the basic necessities to survive the next day. it a little bit funny how the music is so calming when your constantly rushing the survivors, but that is little comfort where the biggest problems come from scavengingYou can only scavenge at night and have a limited amount of time like daytime, the character you choose can depend on how much they can carry and its a very big factor in this game. you only have a limited amount of slots and how much you have can carry can depend on life and death. but the areas that are safe from hostile are finite, and soon you will have to be robbing bandits or military outposts, or worst of all, other survivors.now the combat in this game also works well and there are various areas where you can hide and take cover. the combat it even more intense with a permadeath system that if you one of your survivors die, they die for good. the combat isn't really hard once you get the hang of it but that is not the worse of it.the game has a built in mood mechanic that changes if the characters do something heroic or evil. now keep in mind you do control your characters and not their personality, if you get them to kill a bandit or soldier or save someones life, they'll be happy or care very little. But if you get them to kill or rob a survivor, sometimes they'll become depressed to the point that they will start crying or worse, commit suicide. their mood can depend on what they will do and if they are content, they will be really hard to depress unless its extreme scenarios, if they are their movement is lowered and their actions take longer. it's a very well implemented mechanic that is very fitting for the game tone.artificial intelligencethe npc have their own personalities and reactions to the presence of the controlled survivor when your spotted by them. there are ones that will just ignore you, or threaten you to leave if they are survivors or sometimes soldiers. then there are ones that will kill you on site which are bandits and mostly soldiers. the game has a health bar and if their health is really low, sometimes they will beg for mercy, or run if you killed most of their team. If your not spotted and watch them, they have their own idle animation, like reading a book or going to sleep.atmospherethe whole game itself is as depressing as the trailer said it would be. you will be constantly having to get needs that shouldn't be hard to get in our time, like food, water medicine, and a lot of other problems that are death threatening. even the beginning of the game when you first start has no other button in the menu, except the word "survive".The background also sets the tone for the rest of the game like a pair of shackles with a man and a child holding hands and looking out to the distance of smoke and decay, with a dilapidated wall saying "♥♥♥♥ the war". you start it up and here you go, a group of survivors and a little backstory of these poor people, and the rest is up to you. I did manage to survive on my first run but was the worst play in my life which i didn't want to do. one survivor died, and another with post traumatic stress disorder.there is no hand holding in this game, there is even no tutorial, because it wants you to push you to the limits. its a look into the cries of people that have never been heard or given a lot of justice. your group is no superhero, they are like you and even feel remorse from the pain of others. you can go through the game without killing outright good people, but you still won't save everyone. the whole game isn't bleak and depressing, you can help others in times of needs like giving medicine to children. It will give you a massive smile on your face when you get as many people out of this alive and still pure to themselves, i sure did.negatives the whole placement of stuff can be an♥♥♥♥♥ especially where the buttons are placed. putting the "end day" button next to "our stuff" has led to many days where i couldn't finished my tasks because i tried to look at our inventory. now you can exit and reload the save, but it goes back to the beginning of the day and then you have to do it all over again.the ai in combat is also thick as well, here's a scenario.two soldiers kill a rebel, i'm hiding and when one of them falls down the hole i kill a soldier, i though he would leg it but my survivor can hear him climbing the ladder to where i am and i wait for him with the shotgun, then i kill him. what im saying is that if i was somewhere where there was one entrance. every armed enemy will come rushing at you one by one. a little bit more thought into the characters ai would have made for an engrossing experience.conclusionthe whole game is set in a make believe country of Poregon and even that it makes a good impression to be one of my favorite games. It's a game where every single problem you experienced is because of war. there is nothing good coming from it for any good person. it works well as a game that conveys its message. this is a game that manages to help people understand the struggles of refuges.and if you think the war child charity is a scam, herehttp://www.polygon.com/2015/4/2/8331411/this-war-of-mine-charity-dlcthere is dlc for the game and each has funds towards war-child, a charity for chidren in war torn countries. the game will teach you something like "Undertale" and if your a parent, buy this game for your child or children. you will not regret it.

												i forgot to put woods into the heater and everyone basically just got sick and left/died.I went to the old couples house and stole their med and found both of them dead the second time I got there.I felt really bad for what I did for a few days.And I NEVER went back to that quiet house.This is the game thats not necessarily fun but it haunts you and really makes you think.Now I try to warm up the house even when it's summer.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 10
												A really well made game!You can easily get attached to the characters in the game, expecially with "The Little Ones" DLC.I remember letting my people starve for days, because of lack of food, but NOT the child. Hearing the kids cry is really heartbreaking in the game, or when your favourite survivor dies.Gameplay is two part.1st:You are at your home base, taking care of things, like getting people to rest, make warm food, improve your shelter and that kind of stuff. This is where you usually get faced with the things you did during the night. (When someone is so broken, because s/he had to kill some elderly people for some food, and won't move)2nd:The night time, the game is mostly wants you to be sneaky as much you can, since you are just a weak civilian even a few knife wound could kill you. You can trade, loot, rob, kill, break down wooden objects to get the things you need to survive.Once you get a hold of a decent weapon, and enought ammo (the easiest way for me was just killing a bandit by hitting the back of his head with a crowbar) the game turns a bit easier, but still its difficult, you are not get to become a Rambo, so taking out multiple enemies without cover is still suicide.And you don't want to die, because of the others...10/10

content:
Posted: March 27
												I cannot begin to describe the grip this game has on you when you play it. It may be a full fledged game, but in my opinion is also an experience. If you like survival/simulation games but also want a story, this game will do wonders for you. Rather than being merely another shooter where you gun down wave after wave of armed foes, this game shows the real impact of war - not just on those fighting one, but those caught inside of one. Definitely something for all to try out.

content:
Posted: November 21, 2016
												The most impressing event i experienced is passing the Sniper Junction, an injuried father beg me to sweep the sewer in order to look after his child. Although i didn't want to do him a favor: i just wanna steal or rob the diamond, medicine and food,  after sweeping the sewer, the poor man heared the voice and took me to his house( we paused several times because of his injury). By the time i want to kill him to check if i could get some valuable stuff, he just shaked his little cute babysitter and said:'' Baby, this may not your favorite, but you have to eat it all." Then, he showed me a box which has 5 diamonds. I couln't see his expression, it must be a big sweet smile i guess.  For the first time playing the game, i had killed so many soldiers, the common people( even the old Couple). I felt shame on myself, i just killed the old Couple yesterday night in Quiet House and found 2 diamonds from the old lady. I simplely consider it as a war game, just a game!  SO i became a evil killer regardless of others lives. As results, my role didn't survive 2 weeks. As an anti-war game, it left big impression on my inside. And i absolutely believe that i cannot survive in Modern War.   May no war exist anymore! May peace fills with the whole world.

It will give you a massive smile on your face when you get as many people out of this alive and still pure to themselves, i sure did.negatives the whole placement of stuff can be an♥♥♥♥♥ especially where the buttons are placed. putting the "end day" button next to "our stuff" has led to many days where i couldn't finished my tasks because i tried to look at our inventory. now you can exit and reload the save, but it goes back to the beginning of the day and then you have to do it all over again.the ai in combat is also thick as well, here's a scenario.two soldiers kill a rebel, i'm hiding and when one of them falls down the hole i kill a soldier, i though he would leg it but my survivor can hear him climbing the ladder to where i am and i wait for him with the shotgun, then i kill him. what im saying is that if i was somewhere where there was one entrance. every armed enemy will come rushing at you one by one. a little bit more thought into the characters ai would have made for an engrossing experience.conclusionthe whole game is set in a make believe country of Poregon and even that it makes a good impression to be one of my favorite games. It's a game where every single problem you experienced is because of war. there is nothing good coming from it for any good person. it works well as a game that conveys its message. this is a game that manages to help people understand the struggles of refuges.and if you think the war child charity is a scam, herehttp://www.polygon.com/2015/4/2/8331411/this-war-of-mine-charity-dlcthere is dlc for the game and each has funds towards war-child, a charity for chidren in war torn countries. the game will teach you something like "Undertale" and if your a parent, buy this game for your child or children. you will not regret it.

												A really well made game!You can easily get attached to the characters in the game, expecially with "The Little Ones" DLC.I remember letting my people starve for days, because of lack of food, but NOT the child. This is where you usually get faced with the things you did during the night. (When someone is so broken, because s/he had to kill some elderly people for some food, and won't move)2nd:The night time, the game is mostly wants you to be sneaky as much you can, since you are just a weak civilian even a few knife wound could kill you. You can trade, loot, rob, kill, break down wooden objects to get the things you need to survive.Once you get a hold of a decent weapon, and enought ammo (the easiest way for me was just killing a bandit by hitting the back of his head with a crowbar) the game turns a bit easier, but still its difficult, you are not get to become a Rambo, so taking out multiple enemies without cover is still suicide.And you don't want to die, because of the others...10/10

I felt so ashamed I didn't bother them any longer. I left meds for them and took some food, not all of it. I left promptly with my crew feeling ashamed.Like i said, rite in the feels ;(

content:
Posted: March 19, 2015
												This has got to be one of the most beautifully done games I have ever played. In itself you find yourself feeling things you never thought you would feel while playing a game, and balancing those feelings with the sort of life changing actions you have/choose to make.Playing as a survivor during a war struggling to survive from starvation, illness, wounds, other survivors, and the military, rather then a automatic weapon wielding one man army sent to slaughter hundreds of enemies in the name of your country/organization/religion/whatever. And its that sort of thinking outside the box with how most games are being done now that makes this game a true piece of art.The combat is unforgiving, just as it should be. If you choose to engage in some kind of combat you had better be prepared to really think about how you are going to take on the obstacles in front of you. Its easy to get wounded, get chased off, or even die if you are not careful.Scavenging during the night also plays its role, having to balance what is necessary with what isn't. Planning for the future winter by stocking up on canned goods and firewood. Getting the tools and materials needed to truly secure your home, and fix it up with facilities to keep your survivors both happy and alive. Mix in a little trading and you really need to look at all your looting options. Do you take the can of food? Do you really need it? Or is the pile of wood a better choice? Sometimes you will find yourself really balancing it out to because missing some key pieces when your survivors are either hungry, cold, or depressed can really change how the next few days play out.The music is utterly amazing. Its simple, quiet, and really sets the mood properly with the artistic style the game is designed in. There are times I just left the game on pause while I do some house work, to have that nice ambiance.My advice, play the game as if you were one of the survivors, don't think of yourself as a player/god controlling these people. When you do that you really start to care about your survivors, what their stories are, and what sort of things they are having to do, let alone what actions you take and how it will effect them.All in all this game stands out for one main reason. It has a soul. It doesn't need those million dollar CG trailers, seizure inducing lens flares spammed across the screen, sharks with freakin laser beams, Press X to feel aspects that all the recent triple A games have. Its just a well done game with a soul, and as a gamer what more could you ask for?

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												This game is an amazingly immersive experience. I got totally shrecked the first 4-5 times I played it before I started to become more familiar with the mechanics and how to survive. I made it through the winter and into the spring time when the war finally came to a close around about 60 days in or so. I was absolutely hooked on this game, I didn't want to stop playing it until I'd beaten it. And to be honest, when I finally did beat it I was a little bit sad that it was over. But at the same time, I was happy for my fictional in-game characters. They wouldn't have to do those despicable things to survive anymore. The♥♥♥♥♥♥ murder, and pilaging was over. And then I sat in my desk chair for several minutes contemplating everything I'd done in those 60 days to survive. Thinking about how those things really happened to REAL people back in the seige of Sarajevo during the Bosnian war in the 90's. I've never played a video game that made me think about real life(...and death) such as This War of Mine.10 out of 10, would recommend. To anyone. Play this game now, before you forget about it. Also, don't be put off by the difficulty at first. After an hour or two of playing you will be a lot better at surviving guaranteed.Shout outs to all who had to go through the seige of Sarajevo. I know This War of Mine is just a game, but it's a game that gave me a MUCH MUCH greater respect for ANYONE who's gone through such a terrible war and had to get their hands dirty to survive. And to those who did all that they could to help other innocent civilians while putting their own lives at risk.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												Fantastic.  Yes, it does get a wee bit repetitve after a couple weeks into the experience, but even that helps the immersion in my opinion.  The game relies heavily on your application of imagination and willingness to role play.  I love games that drop you into the world and you provide your own story.  Do you want to be ruthless or go hungry to avoid hitting that one untouched locale with good people just trying to survive?  Do you intervene when people in the world are victimized or take a "better you than me" approach and go about your business while the bad folks are distracted?  It's very much a sim and not a typical war game.  I enjoy it immensely, but once again I'll warn you that the game expects you to bring something to the table to maximize your expeience.  The random nature of the game also allows for a great amount of replay value.A bargain at 20 bucks.  Do it.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												This game and papers please should seriously be a part of a secondary school social studies curriculum. Ive actually made a personal study of stuff like the wars in georgia and serbia and this game does a great job with the atmosphere of dread one could expect from living through that.But this game also takes it a step further and proves why games are an awesome medium for serious art, in any other medium if the story ended with everyone dying of either murder or starvation your reaction would probably be "Oh, I guess it was intended to be a downer story."But here, where survival is in your hands and your control your reaction to every setback is very visceral. You're cursing the cold, you hate those thugs and want to get back at them and youre just in a daze about eight hours in wondering how much longer could this war possibly go on, its gotta be almost over right? The feeling of helplessness as a player really does a lot to help it sink into you just how terrible these conditions would be to live through. "Everyone should choose one happy memory. And it can't be good, it has to be grand. When it gets so bad you just want to sit down and cry, when your life seems forfeit, you close your eyes and go back to your happy moment. It's not easy, but you have to try."  - MarkoAnd then he died, like the NEXT day. Out gathering supplies in an abandoned church and from seemingly out of nowhere gets stomped to the ground by some guy with a shotgun who just executes him in cold blood.This game is HARSH. And I love it for being that way.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
												The game has you managing your supplies by determining who gets to eat, and who gets medical treatment if sick. Gathering supplies from outside (Only at night since it’s safer) has you putting your home at risk from looters if not properly protected. Also building improvements like barricades, beds, booking facilities, moonshine stills, all help to keep your civilians alive. Even keeping the house warm with a stove becomes imperative, when deciding to use fuel for either cooking or heating.The game has no tutorial or instructions on what the best approach is, rather it’s left up to you. Do you want to survive? Help others? Become bandits and rob others? Even take part in the war by attacking military posts. All rather difficult tasks, and none really goes through as planned.My game started off with three young men, Marko, Bruno, and Pavle. Bruno was the cook who feared venturing out, caring only for survival. With the mentality, better them than us. Marko and Pavle the strongest of the two as far as scavenging and defending. As the game progressed I ran into an elderly man named Anton who excelled in creating items and gave him shelter.The game has you investing in your characters and fabricating their personalities in your mind as you make choices that put them at risk. Towards the end of my game winter sets in and supplies become scarce, while sickness becomes more common. Pavle ends up dying trying to back home through Snipers alley, an obvious reason why it’s called that. Marko dies trying to steal supplies from bandits that own a brothel. Left with a sick Anton and the cowardly Bruno. I set Bruno to avenge Marko as a last ditch effort. I imagined Bruno having lost his fear in desperation and anger. Making him kill three armed men with a shovel as he ambushed them from different locations of their hideout. The risk brought in a big reward.However returning home he only found that Anton froze to death in his bed. Bruno was now alone, suffering depression, but getting what he wanted from the start, just to survive.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												This game is so sad. I don't mean that in a negative way, either. It forces you to make tough decisions. Will you try and play the righteous path, where you barter and trade with your neighbors? Good. However, what if the trader doesn't have what you need at the moment? You don't want to let your group starve, do you? Well let's go scavenge a nearby building for food and supplies. You sneak into the structure, gathering food and building materials to just try and get you buy. You aren't taking everything, heck, you can't even carry that much. As you're searching through the cabinets for the canned goods and medicine you need, a hostile opens the door to your right and attempts to unload a magazine of ammunition at you. Through quick thinking, you descend down the stairs and wait for him in the dark corner so you can achieve the element of surprise on your well armed oppenent. He rounds the corner, and you stab him until he collapses onto the floor with a gurgling thud. You begin looting his ammunition when you hear more footsteps descending down the stairs. You ready yourself for the second onslaught, but it passes you by an collapses on your former opponents corpse into a sobbing heap. When the red haze of bloodlust clears, you realize that it was an elderly man and his wife. She moans uncontrollably and laments the fact that her love is now gone. He wasn't a hostile looter, he was an elderly man in a secluded building trying to make sure no one stole his sick wifes medication. You then have an epiphany. You realize that he wasn't an evil doer bent on ending your life. You realize that you, in fact, are the bandit.Edit: Before the trolls come out from under their bridges, no this actual scenario doesn't happen in the game. I wrote a short fictional story to avoid spoilers. This TYPE of thing does happen, however.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												This War of Mine is amazing. It has the old ‘just one more turn’ quality common to games like Civilisation and as a consequence will consistently keep you up well into the morning hours. The game is defined by several layers of play, all of which fit seamlessly together in forming a deeply moving and often ‘emotionally taxing’ experience. The first layer-of-play is orientated around exploration and scavenging in which you will be called upon to move, point-and-click style, three protagonists around your base and various other environments in search of building materials, food and weapons. The second layer-of-play is the crafting system in which you will be called upon to manage supplies, upgrade equipment and maintain existing infrastructure in the bombed-out apartment block you call home. The third layer is defined by character management in which you will have to carefully maintain the physical and psychological health of your characters through the provision of food, supplies and entertainment. The forth layer involves the strategic map which allows you to journey to other locations around the besieged city, collect supplies and interact with various realistically depicted NPCs. The fifth layer manifests as a very intense platform-based stealth system which allows you to kill, sneak and steal in various environments. The sixth layer is defined by an emergent morality system in which both NPCs and your characters react realistically to your actions, lamenting death, cursing murder and ultimately resorting to begging and sadism under different circumstances. The seventh and final layer involves interacting with NPCs for trade and barter. All of these layers-of-play blend together extremely well, providing a highly immersive experience. The game makes you truly feel like you are a survivor on the brink and demands much in the way of emotional fortitude when you put your characters in harms’ way. I cannot recommend this game enough. 10/10.

Posted: December 28, 2015
												A really great game, every action that you take makes you take a second and think about it. The characters make you feel regret if you steal or murder others to survive. When I played this game, I felt as if I were struggling with them. Early on I was scared of everybody, people who knocked on my door, people where you could scavage. However, as you continue to play, you realize that everybody is trying to survive as well. Some may want to help, some may need help, and some are just thugs trying to get by. There's a reason for every action that takes place in this game, and the developers have done an amazing job on simulating the emotion and issues that these characters face. For example, when I was running low on everything, I decided to scavage the quiet home. There were only 2 people in that house, an elderly couple who could not fight back. They pleaded for mercy, they had many materials, but everytime I would loot something, the old man would beg for me to leave and to not raid them. I felt bad raiding their things, knowing that they would perish because of my actions. I tried to ignore it, however when I got back to the safehouse, every member had judged me. They were mentioning how cruel the character I controlled was, because I had stolen from a defenseless couple.This game however could improve a little on its story and variety. Sometimes you feel as if it's hopeless, or that you're not getting anywhere. The cost of crafting neccessities may be a bit high sometimes, and can cause problems even after you've gathered enough supplies. This is a definite purchase, even for its price.8.5/10

content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												This game and papers please should seriously be a part of a secondary school social studies curriculum. Ive actually made a personal study of stuff like the wars in georgia and serbia and this game does a great job with the atmosphere of dread one could expect from living through that.But this game also takes it a step further and proves why games are an awesome medium for serious art, in any other medium if the story ended with everyone dying of either murder or starvation your reaction would probably be "Oh, I guess it was intended to be a downer story."But here, where survival is in your hands and your control your reaction to every setback is very visceral. You're cursing the cold, you hate those thugs and want to get back at them and youre just in a daze about eight hours in wondering how much longer could this war possibly go on, its gotta be almost over right? The feeling of helplessness as a player really does a lot to help it sink into you just how terrible these conditions would be to live through. "Everyone should choose one happy memory. And it can't be good, it has to be grand. When it gets so bad you just want to sit down and cry, when your life seems forfeit, you close your eyes and go back to your happy moment. It's not easy, but you have to try."  - MarkoAnd then he died, like the NEXT day. Out gathering supplies in an abandoned church and from seemingly out of nowhere gets stomped to the ground by some guy with a shotgun who just executes him in cold blood.This game is HARSH. And I love it for being that way.

												Fantastic.  Yes, it does get a wee bit repetitve after a couple weeks into the experience, but even that helps the immersion in my opinion.  The game relies heavily on your application of imagination and willingness to role play.  I love games that drop you into the world and you provide your own story.  Do you want to be ruthless or go hungry to avoid hitting that one untouched locale with good people just trying to survive?  Do you intervene when people in the world are victimized or take a "better you than me" approach and go about your business while the bad folks are distracted?  It's very much a sim and not a typical war game.  I enjoy it immensely, but once again I'll warn you that the game expects you to bring something to the table to maximize your expeience.  The random nature of the game also allows for a great amount of replay value.A bargain at 20 bucks.  Do it.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												This War Of Mine opens with an Ernest Hemingway quote: “In modern war... you will die like a dog for no good reason.” This is very much indicative of the way the game consciously rejects the action-packed setpieces of countless blockbuster shooters that glorify and romanticize war in favor of portraying war realistically through the eyes of civilians trapped in a conflict they have no say in or part of, fighting for survival and experiencing life at its most cruel.Like a good arthouse film or album of experimental music, This War Of Mine is very much a mood game. It strongly evokes feelings of intense unease, dread and despair, so while I wouldn't say that playing it is necessarily a fun experience, it is an immensely absorbing and compelling one. In a starkly pencil-sketched nation ravaged by civil war (no specific war in human history, just a nameless armed conflict with some Soviet-esque flourishes), you control a party of survivors and are tasked with their item management, regulating their eating and sleeping regiment, nursing their wounds, making decisions about the fates of other survivors they encounter, and essentially keeping them alive. They are just as likely to die from crossfire during a scavenging excursion for vital medication as they are from taking their own lives out of desperation over the bleakness of their situation.While the game ultimately does what it sets out to do, maintaining strong gravitas throughout, it falls short in some areas, primarily characterization. The cast of playable characters all feel cut from the same cloth – we're presented with a photo of each (12 in all) accompanied by a paragraph-long bio. Apart from that (and some minor differences in their behavior and habits), they are quite one-dimensional, moving and acting much like each other and repeating most of the dialogue. For instance, when the 'depressed' condition pops up under 'hungry' or 'slightly sick' in one character's stats and you have another go to console him or her, their very brief conversation always plays out two or three specific ways and you're left to your own devices to fill in the ellipses. Also, much is touted about decision-making being part of the simulated war experience, that you'll find yourself torn about choosing to steal from others or deny them help in order to ensure your own survival, but I personally didn't flinch in these scenarios because the strangers in them are even less well-drawn than the main characters in your own party. Whether this is a price of the game being a small, independent production or an overlooked element that could've been more developed, it stands out all the more because the rest of the game is so strong.You won't always be in the mood to play This War Of Mine, but when you are, it hits the spot like no other game I've experienced. I applaud 11 Bit Studio's choice to take a bold, unexplored approach to this subject matter in this medium, further demonstrating that videogames are a valid art form capable of evoking feelings, setting atmosphere, and storytelling just as vividly and stylishly as any other.

Posted: October 28, 2016
												This game is an experience, for sure. Whereas most war games focus on tactics and the war as a whole, this game is all about the people: ordinary people trying to survive under the harshest of circumstances. It can be very confrontational to see one of your characters fall into depression or struggle with the moral choices that have to be made during the game.Getting through this game succesfully is not easy. Fortunately there is a great built-in modding community that allows you to customise your game experience, although I do recommend that you try the game "vanilla" first to experience its full impact.The Little Ones DLC adds children into the mix, which to me made the game even more interesting. Interactions between the kids and the adults are endearing but also frequently heart-breaking.Overall I would definitely recommend this game. It has given me an experience that is different from any other, and I expect that it will stay in the back of my mind for some time to come.ETA 11/2016: Devs are still adding content for this. Mad props!

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 2, 2016
												In war, not everyone is a soldier. This War of Mine shows you the horrors of war through the eyes of a group of civilians. Taking quite an influence from the Siege of Sarajevo during the Bosnian War, you are put into a city under siege and forced to survive. Though the gameplay is nothing special, what truly shines about This War of Mine is the message behind it. Survival is tough in this city, and you must do whatever you can to survive. This leads to you quite often making terrible choices to survive, such as  robbing a hospital or a church just trying to help innocent people like you survive  and  stealing from an elderly couple, and if you come back to where the couple was, you find out that they have starved to death because of you.  Ultimately, This War of Mine is more of a work of art than a game. It excels at showing you the savagery of war through the ones most affected by it, but the raw gameplay is honestly not the most fun or enjoyable, at least during the daytime. At night, however, comes the real fun of the game. You must send one of your playable characters to a location in the world to scavenge for food, medicine, and anything else that your group needs to survive. If you're a roleplayer, you'll be delighted to know about the character creator where you can upload a picture and create a description for your own custom character. But if you want to stick to the base game, it can get a little boring. There isn't much replay value, and once you've seen a location you've seen it all. If you're looking for a  gritty Call of Duty style shooter, look elsewhere. But if you're looking for a fascinating tale of how life under siege affects innocent civilians, this is for you. I don't believe that the current price tag is worth it for such a short experience, but if you can get the game on sale, it's definitely worth it.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
												This game is absolutely brutal, and unforgiving.  As a trio of civilians living in shell of a house, you start from scratch and essentially progress through the game by gradually improving your hideout, as you simultaneously stave off disease, depression, looters and hunger.  Balancing all of these competing threats is significantly easier said than done.The game really evokes the grim reality of a modern war, in both its art style and gameplay.  Losing one of your civilians is actually quite emotionally profound; each civilian ha their own backstory and specific skill, but also hopes and dreams, as well as interesting quirk (e.g. smokes, or enjoys reading).  Keeping them alive is tough, but in my first playthrough it was not disease or depression that killed my poor family, but blundering into armed thugs and being shot for their troubles.  As inglorious and abrupt as these ends were, it didn't break the immersion whatsoever; people die in stupid ways in war.  What's more, the civilian deaths deeply affect your fellow characters, severely depressing them.  Let this go unattended for too long, and they may commit suicide.  Brutal.As wonderfully depressing and harsh as this game is (and long; a dev. commentary stated that the war could progress for as long as mere weeks to months!), I did feel that the weapon, and shooting, mechanics could be explained a little better.  I don't really know when the best situations are to use firearms, how to acquire all the necessary parts or even how to use them.  BUT, this is a minor complaint, and reflective of the fact i chose to ignore firearms completely in favour of scavenging as much as I could peacefully, then getting the hell outa there.All in all, a really emotionally profound game thats incredibly depressing, and tough to play for extended periods of time.  I highly recommend it!!

												Big at heart, but shallow on content. TWoM is an artistically ambitious game, with some amazing and stark visual effects, but after a few plays through you'll find yourself at the bottom of the content barrel. The general tone, capturing the enui of living day-to-day life in a war zone, is captured beautifully, while the crafting system and world exploration system are both imaginative. You'll just want more after 20 hours or so. One pickadillo: the English is a little wonky in certain bits of dialog, and even awkward English aside, the dialog could be much better fleshed out. It's like a 3.5/5 stars, but try it anyways if for no other reason that it's an entirely unique concept.

												The game seems overhelming at first, but once you know the economy within the game, it's piece of cake :)most of the essential items are craftable (water, raw food, veggies). two other most essential materials (wood and components) are widely available from loot and trade. I've finished most of scenarios easily.The secret of my success? Hoard assault rifles from bandits & soldiers. They are easy to kill with stealth and shotgun shots (in some maps like the Brothel & Army Base  it allows you to hide on the floor above the bad guys and shoot down on them. it only takes 2-3 shots to kill bad guys using shotgun) . Once you got their weapons, you can barter them  with lots & lots of wood & components to make your shelter well-protected from night raids, and build advanced equipments like the veggie garden.once you got water filter, rat trap, veggie garden, and lots of assault rifles, it's all cake walk :)

content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												So I sent Roman to the Super Market, because we could really use food.  Just in case though, he took a crowbar to pick locks with, or to defend  himself if needed.  As he entered the market and began to look through a junk pile, voices are heard on the other side of a door.  Upon sneaking over and peeking through the keyhole, we see a soldier talking to someone, a female scavenger that is looking through a junk pile.The soldier appears to be a bit... drunk.  The soldier askes what the scavenger is looking for, and she says food.  The soldier then offers her food... but in exchange for a 'favor', offering her to come with him to dine and have some fun.  Oh dear, that... does not sound right.She declines, but the soldier gets aggressive with her, not taking no for an answer.  The soldier tells her that she will starve if she does not go with him.  She again, tries to decline his offer.  He gets angry and attacks her with the butt of his rifle.Time for action!I quietly opened the door and proceeded to walk up behind the soldier and promptly yelled "I AM GORDON FREEMAN" as I knocked him down and proceeded to bash his head in.  The female scavenger got up and fled the store. I proceeded to searched the soldier and earned myself a spiffy assault rifle with ammo.  Also, found some canned food while scavenging the store.We celebrated the next morning with a feast, now having a better way to protect the shelter.11/10.  Would be Gordon Freeman again.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2016
												I really wanted to like this game but for the second time after playing for an extended period of time one of my main characters died from the extremely bad combat system. The first time it happened I tried attacking a stronger enemy, but once you have thrown the first punch the next attack will be randomly generated based on your characters stats at that time. The combat system is extremely unintuitive and I would strongly recommend watching a tutorial before starting your first game.The second time, having learnt my lesson, or so I thought, I attacked an enemy sneaking up on him from behind with a knife. In all other games through the history of gaming this results in an instant kill, but not in this game. I severely injured the enemy who then turns around to fight me. No biggie I thought to myself, I'll kill him with my next swing, WRONG. At this point the awful combat system kicks in and even though I keep pressing the button to attack, my character just stands around and waits for the enemy to take three free swings at him that utlimately kills him.This would not be as bad, if it wasn't for the fact that I had invested a lot of time in the game already, and that the combat mechanics and rules of combat were never explained to me as a player in a good way. Especially as the combat mechanics do not resemble combat mechanics established by hundreds of similar games.Some might say that you are supposed to fail in this game, or that your characters are not experienced soldiers and thus should suck at combat. But in my mind there's no excuse for making the player fail at what they are doing even though they might be doing everything right.Other than that the game gets boring and repetitive rather quickly, it's an interesting concept that does not really deliver any entertaining gameplay.If the random elements were removed from combat I might be able to recommend this game, but in its current state I would not.

												这就是我的战争!《This War of Mine》独立游戏中的神作！横版的2.5D风格，写实向的游戏机制，以及灰暗的画面，都给这款游戏画上了浓墨重彩的一笔。带你体验战争的残酷，让你揣测人心的险恶，这是真正考验你人性光辉的游戏。为了自己活着，还是留给他人生路？你自己来决定！在战火和死亡中挣扎了42天，我活了下来，但是失去了初始的乐观。我尝试过拯救他人，但是被无情背叛，我尝试过抢劫物资，却没有受到审判。难道这就是战争？我扪心自问，这是不是这个世界原来的样子？抱歉了，所有刀下亡魂，这是我为了生存必须做的，我活了下来，但是我的心，却死于战争。NO WAR！NO WAR！NO WAR！感谢加入中文，新年快乐

content:
Posted: October 29, 2016
												This War of Mine ends up falling into the most common trap that games with permanent death fall into: Random chance screwing you over. When you go scavenging for resources you get an overview of what you can expect to find at each location, but this overview does nothing to inform you whether you will actually be able to take any of those resources or whether they have already been claimed by others and you will have to leave empty-handed.The game lost its impact once I realized that success and failure depended on luck rather than my decisions. A valid statement about war, but not something that makes for compelling gameplay. Might have worked better as a book or a television series.

number of helpful: 14 of 26 people (54%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												This War of Mine is like a pendulum that swings from pain to boredom.Day time is boredom: everything you do in daytime is repetitive and monotonous. You literally spend minutes each day passively watching you characters do the same things: cooking, building, cheering each other up. There is nothing positive to say about daytime. You just struggle to keep everyone alive, repair stuff that got broken during the night and various routine. Note that in daytime you can't even go out of the house and the occasional traders or npc interactions are completely useless because your team will be to broke/tired to do anything.Night time is pain: you finally get to play the game, but it's so badly designed and implemented it will just result in failure. First of all, the location descriptions is completely flawed, and in most places you'll only find useless gears or wood, even if it says food and meds. Second, you are supposed to kill people (I guess?) But the combat system is so badly implemented you basically have no control on the outcome of the fight. Not only that, but if you actually end up killing someone your dude will get depressed and just lie in bed. Finally, my favourite part, while you have to deal with all this♥♥♥♥♥♥ the npc's can just shoot you on sight and instakill you no question asked, even if you went bare handed. I also find it ridiculous that the game gives you zero explanation of the basic mechanics so that you can ♥♥♥♥ up a multi-hour long run just because you didn't know a particular interactio  (remember that you cant save...), it just feels like an artificial way to inflate playtime.

												This War of Mine is a dark reflection on the cruelties of war. The characters are relatable, the situations intense, and the content pointed.Gameplay wise, it is good enough to support the content. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												This War of Mine is an incredibly interesting take on the survival ascept taking place in a war scenario.The gloomy atmosphere really gives you a very dark and sinister sensation, which fits the game nicely.Note (1): I did spend alot more time than what steam says, since this a great game to play when you are going somewhere with no internet access.You will start up with 3 survivors, who all have their own unique ablities and backstories, which after a while develops a small relation between you and the character itself.All the playable survivors have their own personalities and feelings on what should have been done on some scenarios.You will be given numerous choices that may be extremely unpleasant to deal with.An example is when two kids knocked on my door in desperate need of two bottles of pills. You have the option of turning them down, but by doing this you will mentally damage all the survivors who want the good thing to be done.You do also have an option of thinking it through by saying to them "Maybe Later". They will then leave and come back in a day or two in search for the medicine for their mother.Then there is also the generous, but costly action that gives them the medicine.As I stated in on the unpleasant event of the two kids. There is a morale system in the game that plays a huge role on the game itself, but it also impacts some of the players playing this game.Personally I was in a small emotional roll when having the option to either help or not to.I wanted to do the right thing to everyone beyond my shelter, but I also had to keep my own survivors in shape, both mentally in physically.If someone got slighty sad, they were still operational, but keep talking to themself on what should have been done or why did it have to be done.When reaching a certain point, your characters will become depressed and even broken at some point.When at their breaking point, they will collapse of stress and sadness that is being forced into them. From either an other survivor dying because you couldn't find them help or that you had to go a murderous spree, just to survive the following day.You will be forced into a situation where you will have to do something awful to survive.There is so much depth in the game that really wants you to keep going.At the time I wrote this review there is two bases that you can end up with, There is also 12 survivors that you can be played. The game also has a random seed that randoms the places that your current game can visit, meaning that next time you start a new game you might have a new place that you didn't have in the previous game. What I wanted to tell you is that it has some replayability.I do have to say that this game has a very bright future for itself and I will look forward for new update from the developers.Note (2): I did forget to tell you about other game mechanics, but I didn't have time to write a really proper review with the current time I had in hand. So feel free to ask me anything, if your heart so desires. I will try to answer them as fast as possible, that is incase I receive any.

												This is an amazing game - challenging, unforgiving, and makes you think.  My first playthrough, I lasted for just over two weeks.  One of my people died while trying to save a man from a sniper, another was gravely injured fighting off looters who raided the house in the night.  I sent my third character out every night to find bandages and supplies.  In an act of desperation, I broke into a home to steal supplies, and was caught.  I murdered the man for his supplies, and his wife even though she begged me not to.  They didn't even have any medical supplies, although it didn't matter because the wounded friend died in the night.  The next morning, my last survivor was mentally broken and spent the day sitting on the floor weeping...Hung himself the next morning.You know it's a good game when you have to fix yourself a drink and evaluate your life after getting a game over.  This is one that will stick with you.  Definitely pick it up.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												This is a beautifully done game.  For all you people out there who have romantic ideas about war, try this indie game on for size.  There is a reason why people say war is hell.  As the game says, not all those in war are soldiers, and this game is definitely more REAL and relavent to today's world than 99% of the war games out there.  **Mild Spoiler**I felt bad about stealing that food from those old people.  I'm sorry, but my guys were starving.  I HAD to?  They didn't even fight me or yell at me.  They were broken.  When my character got back, she was emotionally broken.  Literally.  She would not eat, sleep, or respond to my commands.  That's realistic!  Even when I thought I would use Roman, the ex soldier who usually doesn't care about others and also beat the crap out of my good cook, to just pick up this bandage in the hospital, he was sad, too.  I thought no one was using it, but you can see their thoughts, and Roman was thinking: "What if the sick and wounded needed it?"  I left the medicine but Roman almost killed that cook, and I needed bandages.This game could even be educational for all the kids out there that think romantic ideas about war.  And the new DLC is great.  I haven't played it yet, so how can I say it?  Because you can pick how much you want to pay, and 100% goes to charity, to children who are the victims of war.  How beautiful is that?  I'm living on limited income right now, so I opted to pay $.99 cents, and even though it is a tiny amount I needed to make a gesture.  Thanks, devs and company, for helping me feel a little better about myself, on this day of my birthday.10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												A well executed and properly involving survival and managing game.I haven't put that many hours into the game (yet) however I would like to share my enthusiasm about this game with you all. This War of Mine puts the player in control of a small group of civilians in a dire, yet realistic setting in which survival truly is an every day concern.It clearly doesn't need any zombies or post-apocalyptic events to transpire to have you feel you are in an endangered situation. You're in control of a group of survivors with real needs and emotions. The decisions you make, whether for good or ill will decide how they will feel. You're faced with a shortage of supplies and there is only so much you can scavenge and find within your safehouse or that you can craft. The game is solid and you can expect a real challenge from this game, it'll test out your decision making and your management skills. Since, from what I have noticed so far, there are a few random generated matters in the game it offers a proper replayability as well.All in all I really recommend this game for those liking a strategic challenge. However, this game might not be for everyone as it does present itself differently from a lot of other games out there. If you want the full experience out of it I would also recommend you explore it without using any guides or similar as it takes a lot of the fun straight out of the game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2014
												I read someone else say "This is the game we didn't know we needed". And that person was absolutely correct. This game is not about being a hero, it's not a war game with guns a blazing. It will make you read the accounts of eastern Ukraine in the news today to get ideas about how to play it better. It will make you think about how we as a people survive in hardship. We overcome. On the game play and mechanics side of things it is also fantastic. Easy controls that only require a mouse, but everything can be accomplished easily enough. This game isn't trying to break ground in game play. However if you are worried about replay value, don't. The scavenging locations are random and so is the loot. Not that platformers are bad, but I would love to see this game made into a single player, first person, open world game. Perhaps similar to The Long Dark (also a fantastic game so far)..The art is fantastic. It's dark, it's grey, it's hell. The lighting is impressive. All in all I give it a 10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 14, 2015
												The game a is a really well woven piece of work, everything in it from top to bottom works to build a very solid and grim experience. The graphics, the music and sound design, the scavenging and events that happen as you manage to survive longer and longer really brings the world to life. More importantly the game also shines a light on a side of war that really isn't covered by games, in fact it even goes in the complete opposite direction of most games and actively shows the negative side of war on a large scale as opposed to acting like military recruitment porn like the Call of Duty franchise, Battlefield, and many many others. I would recommend the game on the altruistic message its trying to convey here alone, but its actually a really solid survival game that should give you an engaging and immersive experience albeit with a ton of stress. Well, good luck, I hope no one sneaks into your shelter at night and rapes one of your group members. If you want to read about the game in more detail you can find the rest of my review here: http://mouseandcontroller.blogspot.com/2015/11/this-war-of-mine.html.

I really enjoyed how REAL it felt. I actually felt like I understood the hardships of living in a war. I would reccomend this to EVERYONE over the age of 13ish, because of its content. If you have enough money for this game, I'd get it ASAP. This is the must-have game of 2014. No matter how much crap this game gets from the haters, there is no reason AT ALL you shouldn't purchase this game. It's entertained me for hours at a time. 11 Bit studios are one of the most insightful developers out there; whenever I thought of war, it was always about the soldiers, not about the hell anyone caught in the crossfire would experience. They are so amazing for giving me this new view of war. But anyways, you MUST buy this game. No doubt about it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												This War of Mine is a fantastic survival sim with rogue-like elements and a moderate difficulty curve.  What makes the game great is the overall atmosphere.  It is very bleak and depressing in a thought provoking way and it really draws you into the setting.  Unlike in most games, the moral choices you will be making here have real consequences to them, and you may find yourself making morally questionable decisions that make you (and your survivors) feel guilty.The rogue-like elements include a significant amount of RNG that keep the experience fresh when playing through a handful of times after your previous attempts end poorly.  You should expect to lose your entire group of survivors a few times while you are getting a hang of the game, but the process of figuring things out is a rewarding one as you manage to keep your survivors in good health longer.  Sometimes the RNG can cause uneven difficulty, however, as starting in the middle of a cold spell or without any characters with large backpacks can make the game significantly harder.The gameplay is split into day and night cycles.  During the day you use what resources you have gathered to feed your survivors and craft things that will keep them alive and in good spirits.  During the night you can send one survivor out to scavenge from a variety of places utilizing side scrolling stealth/combat gameplay that is fairly barebones but is well polished with no bugs or glitches that I encountered.  The entire game is very well done and it would be nice if this level of polish was standard in the industry instead of an unexpected surprise.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												What an amazing game. The player conducts a small group of civilians in a war, and the objective is to survive and to remain human. Of course, surviving sometimes is at odds with retaining one's humanity, and that is precisely where this game comes alive. From looking into abandoned places to getting into direct confrontation with other people in the war-torn city we live in, the player is faced not with the adrenaline that is usual in war games, kill baby kill style, but with those emotions which actually can be associated to what war-survivors tell when they write their memoirs: fear, compassion, uncertainty, so much uncertainty, hope, and above all, despite for war and those who pursue it. Everyone who ever played a war videogame from the pov of the soldier should play this game. Hell, this game could very well be the basis for a whole new industry that does not only require students to read die welle (germany) or lord of the flies (USA), but indeed requires them to play games in order to look at things in new ways, and truly without much effort. This is an amazing piece of art. The only way in which the word "entertaining" is applicable is if taken in the same sense clockwork orange, or the pianist, are "entertaining movies". Most of all, they are captivating experiences.Perhaps the best game of the year, despite (or perhaps precisely because of) coming from such a small studio, and capable of making a lot of people take videogames more seriously.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												In this game the player controls 3 survivors who struggle to survive a war. Inspired in Yugoslavian Wars, this is an emotional journey of survival and moral choises that come with it. This game settles a dark apocaliptic mood right from the start, so well done, with so much beauty, that can only be matched by very few games out there in the market (journey, flower, limbo). You will grow attached to the survivors in a way that they will put smiles on your faces, and will make you feel like♥♥♥♥♥♥when they're depressed. This is not a game about winning or loosing, how good of a player you are, its about the storys you will tell after the war is over.Gameplay wise, it splits into two parts: - day and night. By day, the players will have to manage the house and the resources. By night you have an option to go scavange in the surroundings in a gameplay that feels like a "prince of persia with guns" (flashback/another world). Some random encounters will challenge your morale and decision making.Even though i reference other games, this game is original on his own. And one of the few games that go beyond being just a game... Its not about scores, graphics, music, sound effects. This is a master piece, this is art. This is a must for any real gamer.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												To survive, you have to make choices, choices you may not want to make, but you have to. The premise of this game is to survive as long during a ongoing war in a city. You start off with some civilians in an abandoned house, in which you can upgrade with more protection and more workbenches. You will need parts and materials to make the tools for your survival. Don't forget food and medicine you need to scavange throughout the city.As you lurk around the city during the night, you'll encounter some people who may want to kill you or others who just want to trade. You also only carry so much back during your scavenge to your safe house, but lets hope also you home did not get raided on your return. One nice touch this game adds is the emotional state of individuals, some can cope better than others, with a cig or a book at least. Lets just hope they don't eventually break down and run away with your supplies.You'll have to manage your survivors well, or else things will crash down fast. The game is of course RNG(random) with each playthrough, you can also eventually select different survivors to start with. Sometimes it can be okay, while other times it can be brutal. If you don't die from hunger, you might end up dying from the cold winter.
